column7: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: On Dec 2nd, in Sirte, joint US-GNA forces conducted 8 Airstrikes against IS militants. Declared target was Fighters. Structure type hit was a Military target. 0-2 civilians were injured.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column17: Six members of the Libyan National Army (LNA) based in were killed in a landmine explosion in the city of Benghazi, Al-Jazeera reported on 3 December.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: Shootout between fighters from Bonyan al-Marsous (Operation Solid Structure)and ISIS reported, one Bonyan fighter injured.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column16: Libya Herald; Al Jazeera; Al Wasat (Libya)
column17: At least one member of the forces allied to Libyas internationally backed government was killed and 17 others injured in clashes with Islamic State fighters (IS) in the coastal city of Sirte. Nine of the 17 casualties were injured in an attack by an IS fighter wearing a suicide vest. Buildings in which the militants were hiding came under shelling from the forces. An IS prison official was killed in Operation Solid Structures 4 December attack and two other ""senior"" IS leaders were also killed while trying to swim away from the Sirte beach side. Al-Jazeera reported quoting Libyan military sources as saying the forces found 18 bodies purportedly of IS militants killed in the fighting. Total of 23 dead

column6: Islamic State (Libya)
column8: Military Forces of the United States (2009-2017)
column17: US Africa Command conducted 15 airstrikes on 42 different Islamic State positions in Sirte.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: Forces loyal to Libyas UN-backed Government of National Accord (GNA-Operation Solid Structure) t said Monday they had seized full control of Sirte from the Islamic State group. In the aftermath during ""sweep and clean-up"" operations in the city, GNA forces discovered the bodies of between 266-483 IS militants (lower figure used). 18 bodies were discovered on 4 December - 248 recorded in fatalities.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column16: Libya Herald; Eye on ISIS in Libya
column17: A senior officer was killed on 5 December as the Libyan National Army lost nine dead in fighting in Benghazi's Ganfouda district. Fighters launched two suicide vehicles towards LNA lines but both were destroyed by heavy gunfire before they could reach their targets. The LNA also claimed to have captured three technical vehicles as well as an ambulance.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: ISIS's News Agency Amaq reported that ISIS fighters had carried out an ambush at the 60 junction, damaging two Bonayn al-Marsous (Operation Solid Structure) vehicles, killing and wounding those aboard.

column6: Military Forces of the United States (2009-2017)
column7: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: On Dec 5th, in Sirte, joint US-GNA forces conducted 5 Airstrikes against IS militants. 30-50 civilians were killed and 63 were injured.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: The Islamic State group claimed on 5 December that it had ambushed two tanks (Operation Solid Structure) at Check Point 60 (Buwabat Siteen) 60 kilometres south of Misrata on the main southern highway beyond Tawergha at the junction with the road heading west to Bani Walid. There has been no comment from Bunyan Marsous forces on the report. The militants claimed to have killed 18 BM fighters in this ambush and in the final fighting in Sirte.

column6: Islamic State (Libya)
column17: Three decomposed bodies were found near the town of Obohadi south Sirte. The bodies are of civilians killed by the Islamic State (IS) group. IS were driven from Sirte around 6 December, the bodies were discovered on 27 December but event dated to 6 December.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: 12 fighters were killed on 6 December in ""intense fighting"" in Sirte. Other sources report that 13 bodies of IS fighters were found on the streets in Sirte. The Islamic State claimed its militants had killed and injured up to 50 GNA, Operation Solid Structure-aligned fighters, though this figure could not be confirmed.

column6: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: The Benghazi Defence Brigades and members of Ibrahim Jadhran's Petroleum Facilities Guard attacked Ben Jawad town near the coastal ""oil crescent"", where Haftar had seized four export terminals from pro-government forces in September. The alliance of Islamist and tribal fighters was then repelled by Haftars forces. The air force targeted equipment belonging to the attacking force.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On Dec 7th, in Noafaliya, Military Forces of Libya carried out 1 Airstrike by plane against unidentified militants. Declared target was Vehicle. Structure type hit was a Military target. No reported fatalities.

column6: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: The so-called Benghazi Defense Force and members of Ibrahim Jadhran's Petroleum Facilities Guard launched an assault on 7 December, taking over three eastern towns including the al-Sidra terminal, according to lawmaker Tarek al-Jaroushi, who is the head of the national security committee in the internationally-recognized parliament.

column6: Islamic State (Libya)
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: A wounded Islamic State militant reportedly blew himself up as he was approached in Sirte. None of the Operation Bunyan Marsous, Operation Solid Structure men who had found him were injured.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: ISIS claimed to have carried out an ambush on the Coastal Road 50km west of Sirte, destroying three Bonyan al-Marsous (Operation Solid Structure) technicals, killing and wounding eight fighters.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: The Libyan National Army (LNA) recaptured the towns of Ben Jawad and Nufliya from the military force that took them early this morning. It says that four of it soldiers were killed and eight wounded in the counter-offensive and that eight of the attackers were also killed. Fatalities split between events.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: The Libyan National Army (LNA) recaptured the towns of Ben Jawad and Nufliya from the military force that took them early this morning. It says that four of it soldiers were killed and eight wounded in the counter-offensive and that eight of the attackers were also killed. Fatalities split between events.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: The Libyan National Army (LNA) announced that it took control of the Brak al-Shati airbase south of the country and arrested rival troops stationed there since 2014. The ""Third Force"" loyal to the Tripoli-based Ministry of Defence has been stationed at the base since a 2014 agreement with the LNA.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column17: An unidentified group launched a 'double-tap' car bombing outside the Benghazi headquarters of Saiqa Special Forces. The bombing left 18 people injured. There is as yet no indication if the two vehicles had suicide bombers at the wheel or were detonated remotely.

column6: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: The so-called Benghazi Defense Force and members of Ibrahim Jadhran's Petroleum Facilities Guard launched an assault on 7 December, taking over three eastern towns including the al-Sidra terminal, according to lawmaker Tarek al-Jaroushi, who is the head of the national security committee in the internationally-recognized parliament.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On Dec 7th, in Sidra, Military Forces of Libya conducted 2 Airstrikes by helicopter against unidentified militants. Structure type hit was a Military target. 1 militant was killed.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column16: WAL News Agency; War Is Boring; Libya Herald; Menastream
column17: On Dec. 8, 2016, LNA aircraft launched what appeared to be retaliatory air strikes targeting SDB/BDB forces and their allies in the vicinity of Al Jufrah air base, killing field commander Katibat Umar Al Mukhtar and wounding 13 people.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Demonstrations in Tripoli on 9 December in Algeria Square and then in streets in the evening demanding punishment for members of a militia who gangraped a woman. Protesters also demanded an end to all militias and the restoration of the rule of law.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Protests on 10 December in Tripoli, with hundreds of demonstrators marching to the centre of the city, calling for justice for the woman gangraped by members of a militia and on others to join them.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: On 10 December the LNA imposed a 6-hour ceasefire to evacuate families from Ganfouda district of Benghazi. Militants however started firing when the families tried to leave.

column6: Rioters (Libya)
column17: Salafists attack mosque in Zliten

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Four soldiers, including a Special Forces Field Commander, were killed in fighting in Ganfouda district of Benghazi on 11 December.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On Dec 12th, in Sokna, 1 Airstrike by plane was conducted by Military Forces of Libya against unidentified militants. Declared target was Fighters. Structure type hit was a Military target. 5-10 militants were killed.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: The least 11 soldiers died and eight were injured during heavy fighting as the Libyan National Army worked its way further into Benghazi's Ganfouda district. Airstrikes and artillery fire preceded the advance.

column6: Military Forces of the United Arab Emirates (2004-)
column17: On Dec 16th, in Benghazi (Ganfouda) 1 Airstrike by plane was conducted by Military Forces of United Arab Emirates. Structure type hit was a House. 0-2 civilians were killed and 1-2 were injured.

column6: Abu Salim Brigade
column7: Government of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column9: Government of Libya (2014-) General National Congress
column16: Asharq AlAwsat; Libya Business Info; Libya Herald
column17: Heavy clashes erupted on 16 December between forces loyal to Libya's ""salvation"" government (which is not internationally recognized) and forces loyal to the UN-backed unity government's presidential council in Tripoli's Hay Al-Akwah area, by the elevated Airport Road next to the Abu Sleem district. According to reports they started after an armed group tried to take the area from the so-called Abu Sleem Central Security Force, headed by Abdul Ghani Kikli (also known as Ghneiwa). This in turn had supposedly followed the arrest by Ghneiwa's forces of a man allegedly involved in robbery and murder.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: The Libyan National Army continued to advance into Ganfouda district of Benghazi, advance cost the lives of three more soldiers and five IS and ex-Ansar al-Sharia militants. It was reported that the size of the militant enclave shrank a few blocks as the army advanced.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Property destruction: Zawias Combined Cycle Gas Turbine (CCGT) power station was attacked on 18 December by an armed group and staff were forced to disconnect power lines to Tripoli and its suburbs.

column6: Islamic State (Libya)
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: An Islamic State suicide bombing targeting forces loyal to Marshal Khalifa Haftar in Libyas second city Benghazi on 18 December killed between seven soldiers and wounded nine. A suicide bomber in a small vehicle exploded in the Qanfouda region. A commander of the 276 Brigade was killed in a land mine explosion.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: President of the Libyan General Federation of Trade Unions was subjected to a failed assassination attempt at dawn today, as her booby-trapped car exploded just before riding it.

column6: Islamic State (Libya)
column17: There are confused reports that Islamic State militants seized a remote pumping station on the Man-Made River, taking hostages and sacking the place before withdrawing. The attack took place on 20 December some 60 kilometres north of Ash Shwayrif.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: A landmine explosion killed three soldiers including a brigadier general in Busnaib area of Benghazi on 21 December.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column9: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: A senior army officer was killed on 21 December. He was a commander of the engineering unit of the Zawia Martyrs' Brigade and was killed in a land mine explosion in Ganfouda district of Benghazi.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: A 45 year old woman was hit in the shoulder by a sniper in Sabri district of Benghazi. It is being said that at the time of the shooting there was no one else near the victim. This is being taken to prove that the militants in Sabri are deliberately targeting civilians.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: A man and his wife were killed in a drone strike on their home in Ganfuda

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Two separate bombs exploded on 21 December inside Benghazi Medical Centre. No one was seriously hurt in either explosion although damage was extensive.

column6: Awlad Suleiman Ethnic Militia (Libya)
column17: Renewed tribal violence in Sabha, which began on 24 December, saw five deaths, including two children, as well as at least 15 injured. Sebha is now reported to be calm but tense.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column9: Police Forces of Libya (2016-) Criminal Investigations Department
column17: Two members of the Criminal Investigation Department (also known as the Counter Crime Agency) were kidnapped and assassinated. Their bodies were found on 25 December in Tripolis Hadba area.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: The Libyan National Army's (LNA) Air Force, allied to Khalifa Hafter and the House of Representatives (HoR), conducted airstrikes against the Benghazi Defence Brigade in the town of Hun, Jufra after reports of a fresh attack on oil infrastructure being prepared there. A spokesperson for the LNA said that MiG-23 aircraft carried out ""preventive air strikes"" against the Benghazi Defence Brigades ""to abort suspicious movements"".

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Misrata's Third Force said that it had beaten off an attack by a Libyan National Army-allied unit on of the Gwirat Al-Maal checkpoint on the main road north of Sebha. There were no reports of any casualties in the firefight which is supposed to have lasted for around three hours. Fighting at the Gwirat Al-Maal checkpoint 17 kilometres north of Sebha (near Tamanhint airbase) was between a mix of Magarha and Qaddadfa members plus Tebus and members of Sudan's Darfur rebel Justice and Equality Movement (acting under the LNA umbrella).

column6: Police Forces of Libya (2016-) Criminal Investigations Department
column17: Two policemen from the Criminal Investigation Department were killed in a shootout in Surman on 27 December.

column6: Rioters (Libya)
column17: Roads were blocked and tyres were set on fire in the Bab Ben Ghashir police station area of Tripoli after reports that two policemen from the Criminal Investigations Department were kidnapped and killed. Gunfire was also heard in the area in reaction to the report of the two policemen's deaths.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: Airstrike - 27 Dec 16, Al Jufrah, Hun: LNA air assets launched an airstrike against a BDB camp in Houn, Jufra.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Inter-militia fighting was reported, including militias from or allied to Haithem Tajuri's Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigades, over the last three days in the Abu Saleem and Ain Zara areas, with reports of revenge action for the killing of one militia member.

column6: Rioters (Libya)
column17: Gunmen closed the road heading north from Gharyan to Gawasim on the way to Aziziya. They were demanding the release of colleagues arrested last week after they set up illegal checkpoints on the road.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Inter-militia fighting was reported, including militias from or allied to Haithem Tajuri's Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigades, over the last three days in the Abu Saleem and Ain Zara areas, with reports of revenge action for the killing of one militia member.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: A doctor was taken on 27 December from Misrata hospital, allegedly by a local security militia. The reason is unknown.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On Dec 28th, in Sokna, Military Forces of Libya conducted 1 Airstrike by plane against unidentified militants. Declared target was Fighters. Structure type hit was a Military target. No reported fatalities.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: A man was killed and a woman kidnapped in Kufra on 28 December.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: In Benghazi on 28 December, there were air raids on militant positions in the downtown districts of Sabri and Suq Al-Hut but no attempt by ground forces to enter them.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Staff at Misrata Central Hospital's cancer unit began industrial action following the seizure of one of their colleagues.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: In Benghazi on 28 December, there were air raids on militant positions in the downtown districts of Sabri and Suq Al-Hut but no attempt by ground forces to enter them.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: In Sebha, staff at the town's medical centre held protests on 29 December over abuse and attacks against them by members of the public.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: Movement of forces: Bunyan Marsous forces have joined police from the town of Beni Walid to scour the area for what are thought to be IS training camps. Bunyan Marsous crews formed road blocks and headed out on patrols. The operations room in Bani Walid is reported to have strengthened local security.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: A landmine killed a Special Forces soldier in Ganfouda district of Benghazi on 31 December.

column6: Unidentified Military Forces
column17: On January 1, an unknown aircraft conducted one airstrike targeting an unidentified armed group in Jufra.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: BRSC allegedly targeted/hit a tank or BMP-1 in the 'Amarat al-Siniyah area of Ganfouda, Benghazi.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Misrata's 3rd Force targeted LNA's 12th Brigade at the Brak Military Base with Grad rockets on 1 January.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Misrata's Third Force recaptured the key Gwirat al-Mal checkpoint (20m north of Sebha near Tamanhint) from the Libyan National Army in an operation which included at least one airstrike.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: On January 2, the GNA air force conducted an airstrike hitting a road near the Gwirat al-Mal checkpoint (coded as Tamanhint at geoprecision 2).

column6: Military Forces of the United Arab Emirates (2004-)
column17: On January 2, the United Arab Emirates conducted four airstrikes hitting houses in Ganfouda, killing three civilians.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: A new round of fighting took place in the Libyan city of Sabha where rival militias are battling for control of the southern region and military bases there, Al-Jazeera reported on 2 January. Fighters loyal to the military council of the western city of Misrata clashed with forces loyal to Khalifa Haftar, the commander of the Libyan National Army that operates in eastern Libya. The aim of the pro-Haftar forces is to seize control of the whole of the southern region and the military bases of Barak al-Shati and Tamanhant, which controls the main entrance to Sabha.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column16: Libya Herald; AFP; Jamahiriya News Agency; AP
column17: The Libyan National Army, led by Hifter, hit al Jufra air base destroying a C-130 military aircraft that was carrying a group of Misratan officials including the Misrata Military Council (MMC) spokesperson when it landed, resulting in one killed and eight wounded.

column6: Islamic State (Libya)
column17: A suicide bomber in Sirte entered a mosque with a concealed suicide belt. He was recognised as an IS member by one of the worshippers who reportedly shot the would-be bomber dead before he could detonate his explosives.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On January 4, LNA conducted fourteen airstrikes against unidentified targets in Hun.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: An ISIS fighter set off his SBELT near a BAM checkpoint in east Sirte while trying to escape, no damages or casualties inflicted. Operation Solid Structure forces targeted.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column7: Military Forces of United Arab Emirates
column17: On January 5, LNA and/or United Arab Emirates conducted one airstrike targeting a vehicle carrying BRSC or Islamic State militants, or civilians in Ganfouda, killing four individuals.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: At least 21 fighters of the Libyan National Army (LNA), loyal to commander Khalifa Haftar, were killed in clashes with Islamic State militants in the northern Al-Sabri neighbourhood and Qanfuda area of the eastern city of Benghazi on 5 January. A column of vehicles is reported to have bust out of Ganfouda and headed south towards Suluq. They are said to have included Wissam Ben Humaid, the militants' leader. 3 militants were also reported dead. Fatalities divided between events (11 soldiers and 3 militants)

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Defusal: Explosive devices were reportedly discovered in a school near the passport centre in Al-Majuri, Benghazi.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: At least 21 fighters of the Libyan National Army (LNA), loyal to commander Khalifa Haftar, were killed in clashes with Islamic State militants in the northern Al-Sabri neighbourhood and Qanfuda area of the eastern city of Benghazi on 5 January. A column of vehicles is reported to have bust out of Ganfouda and headed south towards Suluq. They are said to have included Wissam Ben Humaid, the militants' leader. Fatalities divided between events.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: An Egyptian worker was kidnapped in Libya, it was reported on 5 January. Photos were released of four half naked men sleeping on the ground bearing signs of beatings and torture on their backs. Smugglers reported that a group named ""Ansar El-Sharia"" (Supporters of the Sharia) is behind the kidnappings. This has not been verified.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: 13 militants, all thought to have taken part in yesterday's Ganfouda breakout, were taken to Ajdbiya hospital after blowing themselves up on 6 January when they were surrounded by LNA forces at the village of Saunau east of Ajdabiya. Two soldiers died and four wounded in fighting with militants in Saunnu to the east of Ajdabiya not far from the B11 inland highway linking the town to Tobruk.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On January 7, LNA conducted two airstrikes targeting BRSC or Islamic State militant positions in Benghazi.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: On or around 9 January 2017, unconfirmed reports of at least two incidents of smugglers' fuel tanker trucks on their way to the border being shot at or destroyed by vigilante militias not far from Zawia. The vigilante militias have declared that they will be mounting an operation against fuel smugglers.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Arrests: The Libya National Army arrested Mustafa Al-Sohaibi (Abu Alzubir Al-Ansari, the Ansar Al-Sharia commander who had held Benghazis Gwarsha Gate until the LNA wrested it from militant control last November) on 9 January near Jalu.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Protestors, believed to be fuel smugglers, have shut down the fuel pipeline feeding GECOL's power plant in Zawia. This move follows the accusations from the NOC's chairman of domestic and international fuel smuggling against the Western Petroleum Facilities Guards (PFG) Nasr brigade who withdrew from the refinery. The pipeline belongs to the Sirte Oil and Gas Company and is located in the Bir Tirfas area near Bani Walid, south of the capital Tripoli.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Protesters stormed the Al Madar mobile phone company headquarters in the Sidi Masri district of Tripoli as a counter move to what they say is criminally instigated power cuts forced on the capital.

column6: Unidentified Military Forces
column17: On January 11, an unknown party conducted two airstrikes and artillery shellings targeting BRSC or Islamic State militant positions in Ganfouda.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Property destruction: A Man-made River water reservoir supplying the capital was vandalised at the Bir Tirfas area near Bani Walid, cutting water to the beleaguered capital.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: A number of Tourism Ministry employees organized a small protest outside the building after members of the House of Representatives (HoR) set up a branch of the HoR in Tripoli. They objected to a banner being put up, protesting the ''takeover'' of their building.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column7: Government of Libya (2014-) General National Congress
column17: The head of the self-proclaimed government affiliated to the Tripoli-based defunct parliament, the General National Congress, declared that he had officially taken control of buildings belonging to the UN-backed Government of National Accord (GNA) and that the political solution signed in Skhirat, Morocco in December 2015 and under which the GNA was formed was null and void. Militiamen backing Khalifa Ghwell and his resurrected Government of National Salvation attacked the ministries of Defence, Labour and Martyrs' Families, Wounded and the Missing. A GNA spokesman denied the reports, saying that attempts to take the buildings had failed. The GNA's Presidency Council said following an emergency meeting that it had deployed army units in the capital to reinstate security in the capital and repel attempts to seize government buildings.

column6: Government of Libya (2014-) House of Representatives
column17: A breakaway group of HoR members who fully support the Libyan Political Agreement (LPA) and its Presidency Council and Government of National Accord (PC/GNA), opened a Tripoli branch of the HoR. Pro-GNA members took over the tourism ministry headquarters by the port, putting up a notice that it was now the HoR headquarters, based in Tripoli. The move was apparently sanctioned by Deputy Presidency Council member from Misrata, Ahmed Maetig. The House of Representatives (HoR) in Tobruk condemned the move.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: One member of the Benghazi Revolutionaries' Shoura Council was killed in fighting against the Libyan National Army in Benghazi.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: An Islamist commander is reported to have died in an assault on the Ganfouda militant enclave in Benghazi. The Islamist was reported to be a commander in the Benghazi Revolutionaries' Shoura Council and by another as an Ansar Al-Sharia leader. He was wounded by shrapnel on 13 January in an air strike and is said to have died on 14 January.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Eight fighters of the Libyan National Army (LNA) were killed and 19 others injured in clashes in Qanfuda and Al-Sabri, north-west of Benghazi. Fatalities split between two events.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Eight fighters of the Libyan National Army (LNA) were killed and 19 others injured in clashes in Qanfuda and Al-Sabri, north-west of Benghazi. Fatalities split between two events.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: A Libyan National Army MiG conducted an air raid targeting MSCD on the outskirts of Derna.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Two members of the Saiqa Special Forces were killed in fighting in the Ganfouda district of Benghazi and others injured. Airstrikes were also reported. The LNA is claiming that it has occupied more areas of Ganfouda squeezing the militants into a yet smaller area.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Four members of the Saiqa Special forces, including an unnamed field commander, died on 15 January in fighting in Ganfouda.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: A Libyan air force Mig 23 crashed in Benghazi during an airstrike on Ganfouda. The pilot and company-pilot ejected safely. A Libyan National Army spokesman said the warplane had suffered a technical failure whilst AFP reported that it was targeted by a missile and shot down. The spokesman denied an earlier report credited to a LNA commander that the aircraft had been hit by ground fire.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: The Libyan National Army found six imprisoned former members of Qaddafi's army when they took a building in street fighting in Ganfouda, Benghazi, during which two soldiers died.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: The LNA said that it had now taken the last part of Busnaib, an area of largely open ground to the east of the Ganfouda district where the remaining militants are trapped.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: At least one boat that was reportedly attempting to deliver supplies to Derna was hit outside the port by a navy craft manned by the LNA. There are some reports claiming that, in fact, four vessels were involved, that they came from Misrata, that two were hit and two escaped.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Aircraft belonging to the Libyan National Army (LNA) attacked Derna on 17 January. Several sites belonging to the powerful local Abu Sleem brigade are said to have been hit, mainly weapons depots. Casualties are unknown although the LNA claims to have killed two members of the brigade and wounded another.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On January 18, LNA conducted one airstrike targeting Shura Council of Darnah Mujahidin positions in Derna.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Six LNA soldiers were killed in fighting on 18 January as Haftar's forces pressed with a major offensive to push militants out of all of Benghazi.

column6: Islamic State (Libya)
column8: Military Forces of the United States (2009-2017)
column17: The United States conducted coordinated air strikes that reportedly killed at least 90 members of the Islamic State group at a training camp located about 45 kilometers (30 miles) southwest of the coastal city of Sirte. Controversy surrounds whether the militants fled the eastern city Benghazi or Sirte.

column6: Henish Clan Militia (Libya)
column17: Non-violent activity: An armed group from Zawia again turned off the gas supply to the local power plant. Reports suggest the local Ahneish clan were involved.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Fighting raged in Shaabiyat al-Tira area of Qafunda district, on the western edges of Benghazi. Warplanes also bombed militant positions. It was not immediately clear if Thursday's fighting caused casualties.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Owing to electricity shortages, Ghat, Obari, Murzuk and Sebha have been particularly hard hit, with increasingly regular if small-scale protests taking place in numerous towns in the last ten days. The towns experiencing protest were not specified - coded to capital of Fezzan.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: A car bomb exploded 20 January near a mosque in Benghazi, wounding between 12-17 people including a former interior minister. A security source said the blast was caused by an explosive device placed inside a car parked near Abu Houraira mosque in the central Al-Majouri neighbourhood of the eastern coastal city.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: A car exploded on 21 January in the Dahra district of Tripoli near the Italian embassy killing two people who were inside the vehicle. It was not immediately clear if the blast was accidental or an attack on a militia base or whether the Italian embassy, which had reopened less than two weeks ago, was the target. Al-Arabiya reported that it was a suicide attack

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: On January 21, LNA conducted one airstrike against an unidentified target in Bani Walid.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: A Libya National Army airforce MiG warplane conducted an airstrike targeting the western entrance of Derna. No reports of casualties.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: A senior commander in the 210 Brigade is reported to have been killed on 22 January in a landmine explosion as troops continued their slow push into the main Benghazi militant enclave of Ganfouda.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: At least three soldiers and six militants were killed on 23 January in Benghazi's Ganfouda district as the LNA claimed to have shrunk the area held by militants from some 40 properties to just a dozen.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On January 24, LNA conducted one airstrike targeting Shura Council of Darnah Mujahidin positions in Derna.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Six LNA soldiers were killed in clashes in the Ganfouda district of Benghazi.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Residents of Sebha held protests on 24 January demanding Obari power station finally be completed to help ease the electricity problems that have disrupted the south in recent weeks.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On January 25, LNA conducted one airstrike targeting Shura Council of Darnah Mujahidin positions in Derna.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: The Libyan National Army (LNA) has reportedly taken full control of the western Benghazi district of Ganfouda.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: A commander of 298 Tank Brigade was killed in a land mine explosion in Ganfouda.

column6: Ansar al-Sharia
column7: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Retreating militants in Ganfouda district of Benghazi reportedly took a dozen hostages with them into their last position.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: A car exploded on 25 January in the centre of Benghazi, leaving six wounded including five civilians and a soldier. It was not known whether the explosion was due to a suicide bombing or a car bomb, but the attack was likely aimed at a military convoy travelling along the road.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: Misratan, Operation Solid Structure forces combing the area south-west of Sirte attacked last week by US stealth bombers say they have found 90 bodies in two separate locations. They also reported the capture of two militant suspects and the shooting dead of four more who refused to surrender.

column6: Rioters (Libya)
column17: Angry residents of west Tripoli's Hay Andalus district blocked all main roads leading to the area, as well as burning tyres in protest at the presence of members of the 'Mobile Forces' militia in their neighbourhood.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: According to a Saiqa (Special forces) official, a convey of cars attempted to flee as the Libyan National Army (LNA) attacked what is known as '12 Buildings' in Busnaib area of Ganfouda district in Benghazi. Saiqa apparently killed three of the militants in the ensuing firefight which led to the remaining combatants retreating back to the area. Some, though, may have escaped. During the fight, the LNA reportedly managed to seize eight buildings in the district.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On January 28, LNA conducted two airstrikes targeting BRSC or Islamic State militant positions in Benghazi.

column6: Al-Kanni Brigade
column17: Garabulli municipality reported that eight local residents were killed on 28 January when gunmen from Tarhouna attacked the town, 60 kilometres east of Tripoli. The incident followed the killing at a Garabulli checkpoint some hours earlier of two alleged copper smugglers from Tarhouna. The alleged copper smugglers and the Tarhouna fighters are said to have been members of the Kani brigade, a powerful militia that controls much of Tarhouna and the surrounding areas.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: A Libya National Army airforce MiG warplane conducted an airstrike targeting the western entrance of Derna. No reports of casualties.

column6: Al-Kanni Brigade
column17: Two alleged copper smugglers from the al-Kani Brigade from Tarhouna were killed at a Garabulli checkpoint. According to reports, the two were stopped at the checkpoint and were found to be in possession of a load of copper which they were said to be taking to Misrata. Believing it to be stolen, the checkpoint guards attempted to arrest the two leading to a firefight in which the militants died. Tarhouna Municipal Council said that one of its people had died.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column9: Government of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: A government official was kidnapped when an unknown armed group stormed the finance ministry (GNA) in Tripoli's Dahra district. The gunmen, believed to be part of a militia, attacked during working hours and dragged the head of the budget administration, Nuri Erhuma, out by force. He was released a few days later.

column6: Misratah Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: Change to armed group: Misrata military council (MMC) (Operation Solid Structure) has announced that all militias operating under its control will now join the Central Military Zone of the Libyan Army.

column6: Tarhouna Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: Clashes were reported in Gasr Ben Ghasir after Tarhuna traders, backed by Marghini militia, attempted to assert control over the central vegetable market in Gasr Ben Gashir. Known as Suq Al-Ahad (Sunday market), it reputedly provides Tripoli, 25 kilometres to the north, with some 50 percent of its vegetables. 5 people were reportedly killed.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column9: Government of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: The Audit Bureau in Tripoli reported that their colleague Sami Al-Laafi, was kidnapped on 31 January in Tripoli.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column9: Government of Libya (2014-) House of Representatives
column17: One of the three House of Representatives (HoR) members for Kufra, Jibril Awhaidah, was kidnapped from his house in Tobruk. Formerly a member of the justice department in Kufra during Qaddafi's time, Awhaidah comes from Kufra's majority Zwai community.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Three people who were injured in fighting in Gasr Ben Ghashir the day before are reported to have been murdered while being treated in a local hospital. Local gunmen are said to have stormed the Al-Afia medical centre and shot the three in what is being seen as an act of revenge.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Following a meeting with local elders and security forces, schools in Gasr Ben Gashir have been closed in protest at the armed militias operating in the town, and roads in and out were reported blocked.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Mass grave: Soldiers uncovered a mass grave in Ganfouda which contains an unknown number of bodies. Forensic experts are now examining the corpses, some of which appear to be quite recent. It is unclear if the dead are militants, civilians or captured members of the LNA.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Two residents were killed in west Tripoli's Tajoura district while they were queuing to withdraw money from a bank.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: 5 members of the Saiqa Special Forces were killed in clashes with militants in Ganfouda. An LNA airforce directed an airstrike at apartments that militants were positioned in.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Clashes erupted between forces of the Libyan National Army (LNA) and an Islamist militia coalition in Libya's eastern city of Benghazi. The clashes broke out as the LNA's special brigade tried to advance into the last stronghold of the Benghazi Revolutionaries Shura Council (BRSC) in the neighbourhood of Qanfuda, west of the city. Six members of the LNA forces were killed and 18 others injured.

column6: Wershefana Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: Heavy clashes in the far west Tripoli district of Janzour near Bridge 17 broke out between Wirshefana militias and the Fursan Janzour brigade, with some sources suggesting up five people have been killed and 15 wounded. The fighting over control of the bridge, currently held by the Fursan Janzur ('Janzour Knights'), is said to have started after an individual, allegedly a Wirshefani, was caught trying to steal a vehicle close to the bridge.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Two BRSC fighters were killed and seven others injured in an air strike by the LNA on their stronghold in Qanfuda.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Nine Libyan army solders were killed in the eastern city of Benghazi in clashes with militants after the army took control of the Ganfouda area in the city.

column6: Wershefana Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: Random shelling in Janzour, 25 km northwest of Tripoli was reported on 3 February as fighting between neighbouring Wirshefana militias and Fursan Janzour Brigade (Janzour Knights) spiked when the Wirshefana approached the northern border of Janzour.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: BRSC claimed to engage LNA units in 'Chinese Buildings' area of Ganfouda, Benghazi on 4 February.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: The manager of the Al-Masara Clinic was kidnapped on 4 February. No further details of his abduction are known.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: A corpse was discovered on 4 February in Tripoli. The body was that of the commander of Janzour's Mobile Forces. Emhemmed Azzabi was found dead in the Hadba district in what appeared to be an assassination.

column6: Islamic State (Libya)
column17: A father and two of his children were injured by a landmine outside their house in Sirte. The property had reportedly once been used as an IS operations room.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column9: Government of Libya (2014-) General National Congress
column17: In Shahhat in the east a former General National Congress member Fawzi Al-Ogab was seized in circumstances that are still unclear.

column6: Wershefana Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: A Fursan Janzour spokesman said his brigade continued to be subject to random shelling on 4 February.

column6: Wershefana Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: Clashes broke out in the west Tripoli suburb of Janzour on 5 February. There have been reports of heavy artillery being used and two Fursan Janzour ('Janzour Knights') Brigade members being killed. Five civilians were wounded, with one in a serious condition.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: A television journalist was kidnapped in front of his Tripoli home on 5 February. The abductors told his wife that they wanted him for 'investigations'.

column6: Military Forces of the United Arab Emirates (2004-)
column17: On February 6, the United Arab Emirates conducted one airstrike targeting BRSC or Islamic State militant positions in Benghazi.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On February 8, LNA conducted five airstrikes targeting houses harboring BRSC or Islamic State militants in Benghazi.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Management and staff at the Tripoli headquarters of the Libyan Investment Authority (LIA) staged a mass walkout in protest at the instability and uncertainty caused by the ongoing change in their organization's chairmanship.

column6: Abu Salim Brigade
column17: Clashes erupted in Abu Sleem and Salahedeen districts in Tripoli between the Abu Sleem Central Security Force belonging to Abdul Ghani Al-Kikli (a.k.a. Ghneiwa) and gunmen loyal to Salah Al-Burki, most of them from Misrata. Reports indicate tanks and heavy mortar were used. There was shooting in Ain Zara and Tajoura. One of Ghneiwa's main aides was killed.

column6: Abu Salim Brigade
column17: Clashes erupted in Abu Sleem and Salahedeen districts in Tripoli between the Abu Sleem Central Security Force belonging to Abdul Ghani Al-Kikli (a.k.a. Ghneiwa) and gunmen loyal to Salah Al-Burki, most of them from Misrata. Reports indicate tanks and heavy mortar were used. There was shooting in Ain Zara and Tajoura. One of Ghneiwa's main aides was killed.

column6: Abu Salim Brigade
column17: Clashes erupted in Abu Sleem and Salahedeen districts in Tripoli between the Abu Sleem Central Security Force belonging to Abdul Ghani Al-Kikli (a.k.a. Ghneiwa) and gunmen loyal to Salah Al-Burki, most of them from Misrata. Reports indicate tanks and heavy mortar were used. There was shooting in Ain Zara and Tajoura. One of Ghneiwa's main aides was killed.

column6: Abu Salim Brigade
column17: Clashes erupted in Abu Sleem and Salahedeen districts in Tripoli between the Abu Sleem Central Security Force belonging to Abdul Ghani Al-Kikli (a.k.a. Ghneiwa) and gunmen loyal to Salah Al-Burki, most of them from Misrata. Reports indicate tanks and heavy mortar were used. There was shooting in Ain Zara and Tajoura. One of Ghneiwa's main aides was killed.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On February 9, LNA conducted one airstrike targeting an unidentified armed group at the Jufra Air Base.

column6: Libyan National Guards
column17: Change to armed group: A number of armed factions in the west of Libya, but mainly from Misrata, today announced the formation of the Libyan National Guards (LNG), a group that is backing Khalifa Ghwell former prime minister of Libya Dawns National Salvation Government. LNG forces paraded through the main streets of Tripoli, including Martyrs Square. Similar LNG demonstrations seen in Zawia and Gharyan.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: At least two people are believed to be dead and another 13 wounded following Libyan National Army air strikes on the town of Hun near the Jufra air base. The main target appeared to be the Benghazi Defence Brigade militia, however there are other militias in the area including those from Misrata.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: Two Libyan National Army (LNA) pilots were reported to have been killed when their helicopter crashed in an operation against the Benghazi Defence Brigades (BDB) south of Sirte. The BDB claimed it had attacked the helicopter, thought this hasn't been confirmed. The helicopter was involved in a series of airstrikes against a BDB convoy heading towards the Mabrouk oilfield operated by France's Total oil. An LNA spokesman has been quoted saying that there were at least nine air strikes on the convoy and that five of the militants were killed and 20 wounded.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Mass grave: Local militiamen found the graves of three people east of Sirte. NGOs active in the region said they were discovered in buildings destroyed by conflict.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column9: Government of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: The major of Sirte disappeared along with his two bodyguards on 11 February, around 9 pm while on the road to Tripoli. It is believed that the three were seized somewhere near Khoms, some 120 kilomtres east of Tripoli.

column6: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade
column17: There were clashes in south Tripoli between the Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade (TRB) headed by Haithem Tajouri and the mainly Misratan fighters under the command of Tripoli-based Misratan strongman Mahmud Baiyu, more usually known as Sharikan. Fighting was to do with an attempt by the latter to seize the main highway in the capital. The fighting was in the suburbs of Wadi Rabih, Ain Zara, Khala Al-Furjan and Salahedeen, in which heavy arms were used.

column6: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade
column17: There were clashes in south Tripoli between the Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade (TRB) headed by Haithem Tajouri and the mainly Misratan fighters under the command of Tripoli-based Misratan strongman Mahmud Baiyu, more usually known as Sharikan. Fighting was to do with an attempt by the latter to seize the main highway in the capital. The fighting was in the suburbs of Wadi Rabih, Ain Zara, Khala Al-Furjan and Salahedeen, in which heavy arms were used.

column6: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade
column17: There were clashes in south Tripoli between the Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade (TRB) headed by Haithem Tajouri and the mainly Misratan fighters under the command of Tripoli-based Misratan strongman Mahmud Baiyu, more usually known as Sharikan. Fighting was to do with an attempt by the latter to seize the main highway in the capital. The fighting was in the suburbs of Wadi Rabih, Ain Zara, Khala Al-Furjan and Salahedeen, in which heavy arms were used.

column6: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade
column17: There were clashes in south Tripoli between the Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade (TRB) headed by Haithem Tajouri and the mainly Misratan fighters under the command of Tripoli-based Misratan strongman Mahmud Baiyu, more usually known as Sharikan. Fighting was to do with an attempt by the latter to seize the main highway in the capital. The fighting was in the suburbs of Wadi Rabih, Ain Zara, Khala Al-Furjan and Salahedeen, in which heavy arms were used. The Sharikan militia succeeded in taking positions in the Khala Al-Furjan neighbourhood.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: On February 12, LNA conducted one airstrike targeting Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi militiamen in Hun, killing two individuals.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column16: Airwars; New America Foundation; Libya Herald
column17: On February 12, LNA conducted one airstrikes targeting Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi militiamen at the Mabruk Oil Field, forty vehicles destroyed and thirty militiamen killed.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Protest in Beida in support of a Libyan National Army commander, whose Beida home was raided by armed men after he announced he had quit Hafter's forces.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Looting: Colonel Faraj Al-Barasi claimed that his farm near Beida was fired on and occupied by armed men who were looking for him. He said he had not been at home but the attackers spent some time in the house and had taken goods and cars. He blamed armed forces commander-in-chief Khalifa Hafter and told Alwasat that he was leaving the LNA and the Dignity Operation.

column6: Military Forces of Egypt (2014-)
column7: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Agreement: Egypt's armed forces in cooperation with the Libya National Army secured the release of 13 Egyptians who were kidnapped in the northeastern Libyan city of Ajdabiya.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column9: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Reports of an attempted raid on the home in Beida of the Libyan National Army's former Derna Operation Room commander Faraj Al-Barasi on 14 February. Some reports allege the gunmen were linked to Salafist groups, although it is more generally believed that they were connected to the LNA. There are Salafist Madkhali units working within the LNA. The attackers are said to have come under heavy fire from Barasi's entourage. One was reported killed and later reports suggested that some family members of Colonel Faraj Al-Barasi were abducted.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: Bombs were dropped on Hun by aircraft linked to the Libyan National Army (LNA). Casualties are unconfirmed although some reports suggest there could have been two fatalities. The LNA are understood to have targeted the Benghazi Defence Brigade (BDB) which has been using the base as its operational headquarters. The air force says it carried out three airstrikes, destroying a number of vehicles and killing a number of BDB supporters.

column6: Al-Bla'za Ethnic Militia (Libya)
column9: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: There are unconfirmed reports that the nephew of armed forces commander-in-chief Khalifa Hafter has been kidnapped in Benghazi. It is claimed that he was taken by members of the Barasa tribe in revenge for the abduction of members of the family of Colonel Faraj Al-Barasi, the former head of the Omar Mukhtar Operations Room, apparently seized when gunmen tried but failed to seize the colonel in two separate attempts last week. He has since quite the LNA

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column17: One soldier a member of the Saiqa Special Forces, was killed on 18 February in Ganfouda district in Benghazi, but it is not clear how. It is also being said that two militant suspects were caught trying to slip through the LNA cordon.

column6: Libya National Guard
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column9: Government of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: A motorcade transporting Presidency Council (PC) head/Government of National Accord prime minister Faiez Serraj, head of the State Council Abdulrahman Sewehli and the head of the Presidential Guard Najmi Nakoa, came under 'heavy shooting' in Tripoli. Sewehli accused Khalifa Ghwell's Libya National Guard of trying to assassinate him as the firing came from 'the armed groups based in the (Rixos) Palaces' area of Tripoli. It was reported that two guards in the motorcade were slightly injured. An adviser to the PC, privately say that the whole affair was a fake and is being used to generate sympathy for the Presidency and State councils.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Fighting continued in Ganfouda with two more severely damaged apartment blocks reportedly being overrun by the LNA. This means the militants are now holding just six. The fighting cost the army three more dead and an unknown number of wounded.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: LNA artillery and rockets hit the downtown militant enclaves of Suq Al-Hout and Sabri.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: LNA artillery and rockets hit the downtown militant enclaves of Suq Al-Hout and Sabri.

column6: Misratah Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: The coast road between Tripoli and Misrata was blocked following the outbreak of clashes east of Zliten (160 kilometres east of Tripoli). The fighting was between the Misratan Al-Mahjoub brigade and the Zliten Joint Security Room, a relatively new group tasked with keeping security in the municipality. Two people killed and three injured. The clashes happened in Suq Al-Thulatha, six kilometres east of Zliten and on the border with Misrata municipality.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: A senior BRSC militant was killed in an airforce strike on the remaining positions in the '12 Buildings' complex in Ganfouda, Benghazi. Libyan National Army jets and helicopter gunships continue to pound the apartment blocks where BRSC fighters are holed up alongside militants from IS and Ansar Al-Sharia.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Benghazi's security head, Saleh Hweidi, narrowly avoided being killed on 22 February when a car filled with explosives blew up as he drove between Sidi Faraj and Hawari. He sustained minor injuries, but no one else was hurt.

column6: Tariq Ibn Ziyad Brigade
column17: A man accused of being a fighter with the so-called Islamic State (IS) is reported to have been summarily executed by fighters linked to the Libyan National Army (LNA). A video was released by a group calling itself the Tariq Ibn Ziyad Brigade showing a man kneeling in a pile of dirt in Ajdabiya. The Tariq Ibn Ziyad Brigade is said to be a Madakhli Salafist unit operating with the LNA.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Three soldiers and at least two militants died on 23 February in heavy fighting as the Libyan National Army still sought to overrun the last militant position in Benghazi's Ganfouda district.

column6: Salah al-Burki Brigade
column17: Fierce clashes broke out in Tripoli's Abu Sleem district between the local militia led by Abdul Ghani Al-Kikli (also known as Ghneiwa), and his largely Misratan force belonging to Salah Al-Burki. Whilst the confirmed number of casualties is unconfirmed, some sources say at least eight dead bodies arrived in Abu Sleem.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Mass grave: The LNA announced that eight bodies have been found buried in a makeshift grave in one of the buildings in Ganfouda district of Benghazi. A further 36 corpses have been uncovered in a multiple burials in Ganfouda.

column6: Salah al-Burki Brigade
column16: AP; Al Arabiya; Libya Herald; AFP
column17: Fighting between two rival armed groups in eastern Tripoli continued for a second day. At least eight people, including civilians, were killed in the Buslim and Hadaba districts, where the clashes took place. Rival armed groups battled for control of militia headquarters and the main road to the international airport. Haithem Tajouri, the leader of the Tripoli Revolutionary Bridges, sent in five tanks to support Ghneiwa. Ghneiwa captured a number of positions belonging to Burki in Abu Sleem and nearby areas.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column9: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Colonel Idris Al-Jali, the commander of the 102 Infantry Brigade was abducted on 25 February by seven gunmen who blocked in his vehicle at Ras Al-Teen on the road from the airbase at Maturba, which is 27 kilometres south of Derna.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: A popular Tripoli footballer was released on 26 February after being abducted in Tripoli on 25 February.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Libyan National Army (LNA) troops renewed their assault on militants barricaded in Benghazi's besieged district of Ganfouda on 25 February.

column6: Abu Salim Brigade
column17: A 218 TV channel photographer was seized on 25 February and released a day later. It is reported that his capture was a 'misunderstanding'. His freedom said to have been secured by Hashem Bishr after he was allegedly taken by men loyal to Abu Sleem commander Abdul Ghani Ghneiwa.

column6: Police Forces of Libya (2016-) Prison Guards
column17: Sixty inmates at a police prison in Wadi Al-Shatti escaped when relatives of one of the prisoners attacked the jail to free him. It is understood that fighting with prison guards broke out as a result of the attack, which led to the captives being able to flee. No mention of armed attack.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column7: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: A car bomb hit a Libyan National Army convoy killing two and injuring seven including a Saiqa Special Forces commander. The car bomb struck near a petrol station in Gwarsha. The explosives were hidden in a parked vehicle.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: The Libya National Army (LNA) used tanks and artillery to attack the three remaining apartment blocks in militant hands in Ganfouda district of Benghazi. An army source said that the bodies of three militants, one of them believed to be a Tunisian, have been by found by troops.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Young protesters blocked the Brega fuel depot to demand work. The block led to Tobruk airport being closed.

column6: Military Forces of the United Arab Emirates (2004-)
column17: On February 28, the United Arab Emirates conducted one airstrike targeting a house in Ganfouda, killing three civilians.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column16: Al Wasat (Libya); Al Tanasuh; Al Naba; Libya Herald; UNSMIL
column17: On 28 February, LNA forces advanced in the 12th Project in Benghazi. Between 2-4 LNA Special Forces troops were killed (lower figure recorded). Four Benghazi Revolutionaries Shura Council fighters were reportedly killed in the area. UNSMIL reported that four civilians, including two foreigners were killed in shelling.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Al Jalaa hospital in Benghazi received an injured seven-year-old child, hit in the head by shrapnel from a shell left in Birkah district.

column6: Salah al-Burki Brigade
column17: Non-violent activity: Members of the new Libyan National Guard and other supporters of Khalifa Ghwells resurrected National Salvation Government, such as Salah Al-Burkis Misratan militia, mobilised, erected sand barriers, road blocks and stationed armoured vehicles in expectation of an attack by combined Tripoli forces, including Haithem Tajouris Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade and the militia run by Abdul Ghani Al-Kikli (a.k.a Ghneiwa) both of which nominally support the Presidency Council. The greatest concentration of barricades was in the Abu Sleem area and at Salah Badis militia base at Camp 77, between Bab Al-Azziziya, Qaddafis old HQ and the Nasr forest. The roads around the Rixos complex where Ghwell has set up his government are also blocked by shipping containers.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: A small Turkish tanker has been seized by armed men in Zuwara and the eleven crew members taken prisoner.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: A football coach from the south was shot dead on 1 March in Tripoli's eastern suburb of Tajoura. It is reported that two, possibly three, other colleagues who were with him are missing. He had just met the head of the House of Representatives, Ageela Saleh.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: 15 bodies were found in shallow graves in woodland near Sabratha. It appears that they too had been shot. The bodies may have been migrants, as 22 bodies were discovered on 4 March, killed by people-smugglers.

column6: Unidentified Military Forces
column17: On March 3, an unknown aircraft conducted one airstrike targeting a house in Ganfouda, killing one civilian.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: Hours after the Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi took control of Ras Lanuf airport, reinforcements from the LNA's 152 battalion arrived and staged a counter-attack, recapturing the airport.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: The UN received reports of LNA fighters raiding the homes of presumed Islamist supporters in the Ras Lanuf region, arresting and detaining children and taking hostages. The reports suggest that those detained have been subjected to torture.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: Reports that the Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi attacked Sidra port on 3 March. According to Al Jazeera (Doha) the BDB forced the LNA to retreat.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: The Libyan National Army lost control of part of the oil terminal town of Ras Lanuf to the Benghazi Defence Brigades (BDB) on 3 March. 9 LNA officers were killed, including the murder of an injured officer as the BDB overtook the hospital. A Brigades of the Defence of Benghazi (BDB) column, including units of the former Petroleum Facilities Guard of Ibrahim Jadhran, briefly captured the small airport south of Ras Lanuf. Pictures posted on social media showed Osama Jadhran, Ibrahim Jadhran's hardline Islamist brother, with BDB commander Mustafa Sharksi next to a captured Mi35 attack helicopter.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Following the attack on the oil terminals, a number of pro-BRSC sleepers in Benghazi took to the streets of Benghazi resulting in fresh clashes.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: As the Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi (BDB) military convoys approached the oil ports the LNA conducted airstrikes with jets pounding one column of vehicles at Nufliya, 50 kilometres east of Sidra.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: A series of air raids were conducted by the LNA against the Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi (BDB). The LNA claimed that the aircraft had targeted BDB vehicles but it appears that buildings were also hit in Ras Lanuf.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: Clashes in Um Garanik between Libya National Army (LNA) forces and Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: Nofaliya, Bin Jawad, Sidra and Ras Lanuf under ""control"" of #SDB, #LNA-AF contiues to conduct airstrikes, clashes in Um Garanik

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: Nofaliya, Bin Jawad, Sidra and Ras Lanuf under ""control"" of Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi (SDB), LNA-Airforce contiues to conduct airstrikes, clashes in Um Garanik.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: People-smugglers killed 22 African migrants on a beach in western Libya. The migrants were set to embark from Sabrata beach.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: There were reports that the Libyan National Army retook Ras Lanuf from the Benghazi Defence Brigades (BDB) on 4 March. But later there were reports that soldiers had withdrawn towards Al-Uqaylah and even another 50 kilometres further east to the Brega export terminal. A total of 15 soldiers were killed over 48 hours of fighting. Five fatalities recorded on 4 March and nine fatalities on the 3 March.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Six LNA soldiers died on 4 March in the siege of the 12 Apartments complex in Ganfouda, Benghazi.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: In response to the Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi (BDB advance) on Libya's oil ports, air raids were carried out in Ras Lanuf, Es Sidra, Ben Jawad and Harawa

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: In response to the Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi (BDB advance) on Libya's oil ports, air raids were carried out in Ras Lanuf, Es Sidra, Ben Jawad and Harawa

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: In response to the Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi (BDB advance) on Libya's oil ports, air raids were carried out in Ras Lanuf, Es Sidra, Ben Jawad and Harawa

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: An LNA convoy reportedly came under fire as it moved through Ajdabiya, Jadhran's home town. Three people were arrested and said to be Jadhran supporters.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On March 5, LNA conducted two airstrikes targeting a house harboring BRSC or Islamic State militants in the 12 Buildings area of Ganfouda.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: On March 5, LNA conducted twenty-four airstrikes presumably targeting Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi militiamen in the Oil Crescent (coded as Ras Lanuf at geoprecision 2).

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Women activists in Tobruk protested on 5 March over members of House of Representatives (HoR) joining the delegation lead by Presidency Council leader Fayez al-Serraj to Moscow over the weekend.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: A number of LNA fighters were killed and injured during an offensive they launched on Aqila, east of Ras Lanuf, according to Al-Jazeera. At least five BDB fighters were also injured in the attack.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Gunmen suspected of affiliation with the Libyan [Islamic] Fighting Group and supporters of the National Salvation Government took control of the country's security database system on 5 March. Up until the time that this report went to press, the Libyan Fighting Group has not claimed the attack.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: The spokesman for the Libyan National Army (LNA) denied reports of ground clashes near Derna between it and the Shura Council of the Mujahideen in Derna (SCMD). However, there had been airstrikes on newly discovered mujahideen arms stores in Dahra Al-Hamra west of the town. An SCMD official however claimed that an LNA attempt to advance on Derna had been thwarted and a number of LNA fighters wounded.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: Throughout the day, the LNA carried out a series of air strikes particularly around Ras Lanuf with a heavy raid going in the evening. There were also reported attacks on Ben Jawad and Nufliya on the road west to Sirte and on Sidra.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: There were further civilian casualties from the Ganfouda neighbourhood of Benghazi, including a woman who died in airstrikes on 6 March.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: Fresh air strikes on 6 March hit the Benghazi Defence Brigades (BDB) around the oil terminal region of al-Sidra.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: An unidentified group attacked an academic, smashed up equipment including electronic devices and threatened students studying at Bani Walid University.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Fighting in Ganfouda, Benghazi.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column7: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: There has been shelling of Sabri, the downtown Benghazi militant stronghold which was also strafed by at least one helicopter gunship.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
