column17: Renewed airstrikes reported in RasLanuf, Sidra and Nofaliya on 7 March, effectiveness unclear and no visible progress on the ground.

column6: Militia (Ibrahim Jadran)
column17: The commander of the Petroleum Facilities Guard (PFG), a key militia group that is allied with Libya's UN-sponsored Government of National Accord (GNA), has taken on responsibility for securing oil facilities and terminals in the country. On 6 March many Benghzi Defence Brigades fighters withdrew from Ras Lanuf and Sidra.

column6: Rioters (Libya)
column17: The head office of the Aman Bank in west Tripoli's Gurji district was ablaze on 8 March after being attacked by angry locals after a member of the militia guarding the bank shot a customer dead in the morning.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: On 8 march in Benghazi, the LNA battled in the 12 Buildings area and seized a couple of damaged vehicles + tank from BRSC militants.

column6: Misratah Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: A militia guarding the head office of the Aman Bank in west Tripoli's Gurji district shot a customer dead on the morning of the 8 March. The militia guarding the bank are from Misrata while the dead man was originally from Zintan.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: A man, said to be a member of the Magharba tribe was videoed being repeatedly beaten by four LNA soldiers and forced to declared that Hafter was 'his lord"" in the Ajdabiya region.

column6: Unidentified Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: Arrests: Former Petroleum Facilities Guard (PFG) leader Ibrahim Jadhran was seized by a gang in Nalut. According to the reports, Jadhran was detained by the same gang that he had employed to organise his return to Libya using the Dahiba-Wazen crossing on the Tunisian border. The border post on the Libyan side is controlled by militiamen from Nalut.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Heavy artillery and rocket fire was heard from the Sabri district of Benghazi on 12 March in continued fighting between Libya National Army (LNA) forces and Benghazi Revolutionaries' Shura Council (BRSC) fighters.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Clashes in the last two sections of the 12 Apartments complex in Ganfouda, Benghazi. One (Libya National Army) LNA soldier was killed, reportedly by a sniper, while three people from the complex were gunned down as they tried to escape

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: Reports of heavy airstrikes on 12 March on a range of Benghazi Defence Brigades' (BDB) positions from the front line at Al Uqaylah to Ben Jawad in the west. The BDB claimed that they were delivered by the Egyptian air force. This was not verified.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: Reports of heavy airstrikes on 12 March on a range of Benghazi Defence Brigades' (BDB) positions from the front line at Al Uqaylah to Ben Jawad in the west. The BDB claimed that they were delivered by the Egyptian air force. This was not verified.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: On March 13, LNA conducted one airstrike targeting Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi and militiamen under the leadership of Ibrahim Jadran in Sidra.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: On March 13, LNA conducted one airstrike targeting Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi and militiamen under the leadership of Ibrahim Jadran in Nawfaliyah.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: On March 13, LNA conducted one airstrike targeting Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi and militiamen under the leadership of Ibrahim Jadran in Bin Jawad.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: Seven members of the oil installations guards were killed on 13 March, along with the destruction of a technical workshop in Ras Lanuf port as a result of air strikes from the Libyan airforce.

column6: Unidentified Communal Militia (Libya)
column7: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade; Abu Salim Brigade
column17: Fighting erupted in Gurji when armed locals attacked Misratan and Amazigh units supporting Khalifa Ghwell. Tripoli Revolutionaries' Brigade and Ghneiwa militias came out in support of residents.

column6: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade
column17: Clashes spread to Ghot al Shall in Tripoli between Tripoli Revolutionaries' Brigade and militias supporting Khalifa Ghwell.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Two citizens were killed by an armed group in central Tripoli.

column6: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade
column17: Fighting between Tripoli Revolutionaries' Brigade and militias supporting Khalifa Ghwell spread to the Gargaresh district of Tripoli on 13 March.

column6: Unidentified Communal Militia (Libya)
column7: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade; Abu Salim Brigade
column17: Fighting broke out in the Hay al-Andalus and Gargaresh districts of Tripoli between rival armed groups on 13 March. It was initially sparked by armed local residents and later supported by Tripoli Revolutionaries' Brigade and Ghneiwa militias (Abu Saleem) after the killing of a bank guard.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: The Libyan National Army (LNA) launched a major offensive on Benghazi's Ganfouda district. Three LNA special forces fighters killed on 13 March and an unspecified number of Benghazi Revolutionaries Shura Council (BRSC) fighters killed. An LNA spokesman said that they had made important gains and consolidated its control on some areas.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: Reports that the Libyan National Army (LNA) pushed the Benghazi Defence Brigades (BDB) out of the Ben Jawad on 14 March.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Property destruction: On 14 March, the al-Khadhra Hospital in Tripoli was hit twice by indiscriminate fire, causing damage to the maternity ward and Intensive Care Unit (ICU).

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On March 14, LNA conducted two airstrikes that struck the port of Sidra.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On March 14, LNA conducted two airstrikes in Ras Lanuf, killing one civilian.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column16: Libya Herald; AFP; Al Jazeera; Al Naba
column17: Troops commanded by Khalifa Haftar announced the recapture of the Ras Lanuf and al-Sidra oil installations. The LNA reported 10 fighters killed, the hospital reported 21 LNA fighters were killed and rival fighters of the Benghazi Defence Brigades (BDB) along with Petroleum Facilities Guards (PFG) were being chased back to their barracks. BDB media denied these reports.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column16: AFP; Al Naba; Libya Herald; Al Jazeera
column17: Troops commanded by Khalifa Haftar announced the recapture of the Ras Lanuf and al-Sidra oil installations. The LNA reported 10 fighters killed, the hospital reported 21 LNA fighters were killed and rival fighters of the Benghazi Defence Brigades (BDB) along with Petroleum Facilities Guards (PFG) were being chased back to their barracks. BDB media denied these reports.

column6: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade
column7: Abu Salim Brigade; Special Deterrence Forces
column17: Fighting continued in the Hay al-Andalus and Gargaresh districts of Tripoli between rival armed groups on 14 March.

column6: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade
column17: Fighting continued in the Hay al-Andalus and Gargaresh districts of Tripoli between rival armed groups on 14 March.

column6: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade
column7: Abu Salim Brigade; Special Deterrence Forces
column17: Fighting continued in Gurji district of Tripoli between rival armed groups on 14 March. One one side were the RADA deterrence forces, Abu Saleem Central Security Brigade and the Tripoli Revolutionaries' Brigade.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Al-Nabaa TV was caught up in clashes in Tripoli on 14 March was set on fire, possibly after being hit by RPG fire.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: In the wake of the ceasefire agreement, gunmen took control of Sirte's Gumhouria Bank in downtown Tripoli.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Reports of clashes to the east of Sirte between LNA units and the Misratan 166 Brigade which is in charge of security in the town.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: The siege of the 12 Apartments complex in Ganfouda, Benghazi continued against the Benghazi Revolutionaries Shura Council (BRSC). The BRSC posted that one of its commanders was killed.

column6: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade
column7: Abu Salim Brigade; Special Deterrence Forces
column16: Al Wasat (Libya); Al Arabiya; Libya Herald; AFP
column17: Forces loyal to Libya's UN-backed unity government seized the headquarters of militia loyal to former prime minister Khalifa Ghweil on 15 March. Al-Arabiya TV reported a ""huge explosion"" that hit the Rixos hotel at Bab Ben Ghashir in Tripoli, killing at least one individual and leaving several people wounded. Libya's former prime minister Khalifa Ghweil was wounded in the fighting. Haitham Tajouri's Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade joined forces with Abdul Ghani Al-Kikli's, also known as Ghneiwa's, Abu Saleem Centural Security Force and the RADA Special Deterrence Force to retake control, according to the Tripoli operations' room.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Defusal: Libyan National Army bomb disposal experts defused a car bomb in Brega.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: The LNA said that its aircraft had been striking that BDB 'and its allies' in Jufra and that troops were moving south towards them. Exact date not specified.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Three gold merchants were abducted in Tripoli ""because of their identity, because they are from Misrata"".

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Looting: The National Anti-Corruption Commission in Hay al-Andalus in Tripoli, the ministries of justice, labour and interior as well as hundreds of homes and shops were looted during clashes on 15 March. Key corruption investigation files were stolen.

column6: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade
column17: Small-scale fighting breaking out in Hadba al-Khadra district of Tripoli on 16 March after the Tripoli Revolutionaries' Brigade rejected a ceasefire agreement.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Three reporters from 218 TV Channel were abducted on 17 March but were released a day later.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Pro-Haftar protests in Tripoli's Algeria and Martyr's square against Misratan influence in the capital, Tripoli. The protesters were fired upon to disperse. No reports of casualties.

column6: The Steadfastness Front
column17: On 17 March, Misrata municipal council officers were briefly attacked by gunmen. The hardliners are from a number of smaller militias from the city,all of which oppose both the Presidency Council and Khalifa Hafter. These militias, which support fellow Misratan Khalifa Ghwell as prime minister, include Salah Badi brigade and the so-called Presidential Guard which was formerly protecting the Rixos complex in Tripoli.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Overnight on 17 March, an unknown number of militants was killed when the boat on which they were said to be escaping Sabri was intercepted by a naval vessel. Marine Lieutenant Akram Zalgam said that the militants' craft had been spotted with night vision equipment and sunk by gunfire.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Libyan National Army (LNA) forces have been accused of committing war crimes including killing and beating civilians, and summarily executing and desecrating bodies of opposition fighters in Benghazi. The army forces allegedly intercepted civilians trying to flee a besieged neighborhood, some accompanied by opposition fighters, and the whereabouts of some civilians are unknown. According to witnesses, LNA fighters intercepted about seven families after one of their cars broke down and attacked and killed some of them and arrested others. HRW documents four known deaths, UNSMIL documents 7 deaths (4 women, 2 children and 1 elderly man).

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column17: In an undated video, a captain in the LNA special forces, is seen shooting three handcuffed-men in the back of the head with a machine gun as they kneel facing a wall with their hands tied behind their backs. Local journalists told Human Rights Watch that the executions took place in Benghazi during the final battle for Ganfouda on or around March 18, 2017. The three victims were Tuareg fighters from Ubari who appeared on photos, while alive, apparently in detention by LNA forces.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Mass grave: LNA spokesman Ahmed Mismari said yesterday they had found a mass grave of Islamist militants, including Ansar Al-Sharia commanders and the corpse of Makhzoum. Mismari said the Red Crescent was going to be recovering the other bodies. This seems to have been the spot where the militants took their dead.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Defusal: A car-bombing at Nufliya is reported to have gone wrong when the driver overturned the vehicle. It is not reported what happened to the driver but LNA technicians made the device safe.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: In an undated video, a man in military fatigues is seen being chased out of a building by a mob of more than a dozen fighters, most dressed in army fatigues. They beat, insult, and throw him to the ground, then line up in a row facing him and several summarily execute him with machine guns. Benghazi activists say that this incident took place in the Qwarsha district of Benghazi. Human Rights Watch was unable to confirm the exact circumstances of this incident.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Five special forces members were killed in fighting in Ganfouda district on 18 March. The Libyan National Army announced that the district had finally been liberated. It is now being said that 43 militants perished in the final assault, not 28 as originally reported, including two who blew themselves up as troops came near them.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: A Libyan National Army (LNA) Mig-21 plane crashed on 18 March. It is understood to have been launching a strike at Sabri, which with Suq Al-Hout is now the last militant-held position in the city. The official explanation for the Mig's loss is that this was yet another mechanical failure but some witnesses are insisting the aircraft was shot down.

column6: Rioters (Libya)
column17: There have been public protests against the anti-Misrata protests that took place in Tripoli. A substantial group of Misratan revolutionaries and their supporters gathered at the Dafniya checkpoint west of the city, on the road to Tripoli, and forced its closure.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: ""Three international staff members working for an INGO were detained by Libyan airport security forces at Mitiga airport. They were taken to an off-site location and all faced significant verbal and physical assault. One of the aid workers was nearly raped. The group was questioned about their in-country presence and security-related information. Their personal property and items belonging to the INGO were stolen.""

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On March 19, LNA conducted two airstrikes that targeted BRSC or Islamic State militant positions in Benghazi.

column6: Al-Buni Brigade
column17: Movement of forces: Reports that the Al-Buni militia from Suq Al-Juma stormed the Busetta naval base in Tripoli where the Presidency Council is headquarted.

column6: The Steadfastness Front
column17: Misrata TV was attacked on 19 March by militants who threatened staff. The local radio station was also targeted.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: An Obari bank manager was kidnapped on 20 March by unidentified gunmen.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Members of the Obari municipal council and civil society organisations demonstrated demanding that a kidnapped bank manager be freed immediately.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On 20 March the Misratan Third Force were forced to cede the Gwirat Al-Mal checkpoint near Tamanhint to the LNA forces under General Nayel. The road from Jufra to Sebha was blocked as the Libyan National Army (LNA) mounted a fresh assault on the Tamenhint airbase held by the Misratan Third Force.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: On 22 March, a 12-year-old Sudanese boy was injured in the shoulder in the Ard Zwawa neighbourhood of Benghazi. The circumstances of the shooting are unclear, but there were no clashes in the area at the time.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: the Libyan National Army (LNA) found the bodies of seven of its own soldiers in the complex. It is unclear if they had been captured and executed or killed in the fighting.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Air raid by LNA-AF Mi-35 reported this on 23 March hitting MSCD targets in Dhahr al-Ahmar south of Derna.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Two LNA-AF airstrikes reported in Fattaih, south of Derna, photos purportedly show plume of smoke from the 2nd strike.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Shura Council of Derna Mujahideen (MSCD) clashed with a gathering of LNA forces, targeting them with a 9M113 Konkurs/AT-5 Spandrel ATGM in the area of Wadi Sutabah, SW of Derna.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Rival protests in Misrata on 24 March, both for and against the municipal council.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: LNA-AF airstrike earlier today targeted Shura Council of Derna Mujahideen (MSCD) in the hills south of the city of Derna.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Airstrikes reported in Souq al-Hout targeting BRSC militants.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: The head of the council of elders in the oil terminal district of Sidra was reported to have been seized on 25 March while travelling from Ajdabiya to his home in Ras Lanuf. It is suggested that Abdulsalem Bulahi Al-Maghrabi was taken by members of the Libyan National Army (LNA). 120 abductions have been reported recently in the oil crescent towns of Ajdabiya, Brega, Ras Lanuf, and Sidra - most of them members of the Magharba tribe, and most of them blamed on the LNA. His dead body was found 3 months later.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: A supply boat was intercepted and sunk a mile offshore of Sabri district in Benghazi. The boat is said to have exploded when hit by gunfire.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: BRSC claims targeting an #LNA gathering at the Shajara Square with S-5 rocket resulting in direct hit

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column9: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Air raids on Sabri and the nearby militant district of Suq Al-Hout in Benghazi.

column6: Misratah Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: A local resident was reported to have been shot at near the Tamanhint airbase gate by a member of the Third Force.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Electricity production at the Ruwais power station near Nalut in the Jebel Nafusa has been dramatically reduced after protestors turned off the gas supply. Valves on the pipeline from Eni's Wafa field were turned off near the station by members of the Petroleum Facilities Guard claiming that they were owed money.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On March 27, LNA conducted one airstrike that targeted Shura Council of Darnah Mujahidin positions in Derna.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: On 28 March, a security guard at the National Commercial Bank was shot dead.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Non-violent activity: Pipeline blockade at Ryayina, possibly by militia.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column17: Defusal: The commander of the Libyan National Armys Saiqa Special Forces reportedly escaped a car bombing in Benghazi on 29 March when an explosives-laden vehicle was spotted and defused. The location was not given though it is thought to have been near Benina.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: The LNA have been carrying out air regular strikes on positions held by mujahideen forces in Derna for some time. These have largely concentrated in recent days on the outlying Dahra Al-Hamra district.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Property destruction: The Dar Al-Ifta in Tripoli has claimed its building was attacked on 30 March by gunmen. A Dar Al-Ifta source said that the attackers had been travelling in an armoured vehicle and had sprayed the building with bullets.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: A mine sapper died in Benghazi's Gwarsha district when a device he was attempting to defuse blew up.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: The sharp rise in meat prices brought out an angry crowd in Tobruk demanding a boycott of butchers until the cost is cut.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: 2 civilians were killed by a landmine planted by suspected militants while working in their fields in the Gwarsha area of Benghazi.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: An angry crowd gathered in Tobruk and announced a boycott of butchers until meat prices which have recently risen sharply fall.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On April 2, LNA conducted six airstrikes that targeted BRSC or Islamic State militant positions in Benghazi.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Militants in Benghazi blew up a bridge at Al-Thama on the coastal road heading into Sabri.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: A sailor and a civilian were killed by a sniper in Benghazi on 2 April when a family car tried to cross the Guiliana Bridge.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On 4 April, LNA aircraft attacked Jufra airbase, some 350 kilometres northeast of Tamenhint. It is held by Misratan forces as well as being a operating base for the Bengahzi Defence Brigades. The LNA airstrikes targeted weapons storage.

column6: Zawiya Martyrs Brigade
column17: Movement of forces: A large force comprising mainly the Benghazi-based Zawiya Martyrs Brigade led by Brigadier Jamal Al-Zahawi is reported to have set out on 5 April from Benghazi to attack the Jufra base. No direct clashes yet reported.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Forces loyal to Libya's eastern authorities carried out air strikes on the southern Tamenhant air base where the Misrata Third Force are located. No casualties and Misrata's Third Force remained in control.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Following the first set of airstrikes by Libyan National Army (LNA) forces on Tamanhint airbase, there was gunfire on the other side of the base as LNA forces under General Mohamed Ben Nayel undertook a coordinated push to oust Misrata's Third Force troops.

column6: Misratah Communal Militia (Libya)
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Two aircraft thought to belong to Misratan forces are reported to have bombed Brak Al-Shatti airbase on the afternoon of the 5 April in reprisal for the airstrikes on Tamenhint airbase the same morning. It is not known if there were any casualties.

column6: Islamic State (Libya)
column17: Two men in Sirte are reported to have been killed by a landmine planted next to a major water storage tank. They are understood to have worked for the water company in the town. The landmine is assumed to have been planted by the so-called Islamic State before it was forced out of the town.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Forces loyal to Libya's eastern authorities battled with the aim of seizing the southern Tamenhant air base from the Misrata Third Force. No reports of casualties.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: On April 7, LNA conducted four airstrikes targeting Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi and militiamen under the leadership of Ibrahim Jadran at the Tamnhint Air Base.

column6: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: The Benghazi Defence Brigade announced that it has pulled out of Jufra airbase near Hun and handed it over the general chief of staff of the Libyan army (the army supporting the Presidency Council). It says it has gone to another location, but has not disclosed where.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Oil production at the Al-Sharara field in southwest Libya has been suspended after protesters shut off a pipeline, a refinery source said on 10 April.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Small arms fire reported near Tamanhint airbase on 9 April. No reports of casualties.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: An unidentified armed group, referred to as the Nalut group, shut down the Wafa gas pipeline on 9 April.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Reports by both LNA & SDB sources that LNA-AF has hit a Bonyan al-Marsous camp in Sawknah, no casualties reported

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Additional airstrike targeting 3rd Force/SDB on the road between Zagn and Samnu, and another targeting the Fuqaha Gate.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: LNA-AF aircraft taking off from Brak al-Shati airbase targeted the Misrata's 3rd force at Tamanhint airbase, 3 dead and 7 wounded reported.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Misrata's Third Force said it recaptured the village of Samnu, east of Tamenhint, on 10 April. At the time, the Presidency Council's defence ministry the spokesman, Mohamed Al-Ghasri, said that the 12th Brigade, part of the Libyan National Army, had been 'forced to flee to the mountains'.

column6: Omar Mukhtar Brigade
column7: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Clashes reported south of Jaghub near border w/Egypt between LNA's Omar Mukhtar Brigade & unknown armed group. 5 members from the Omar Mukhtar Brigade reportedly killed, 8 others abducted and 2 technicals seized following attack. Reports indicate Chadian opposition behind the attack.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: On April 11, LNA conducted one airstrike targeting Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi and militiamen under the leadership of Ibrahim Jadran in Sawkna.

column6: Bab al-Tajoura Brigade
column17: The acting head of the Tripoli Civil Registry Authority, was kidnapped by militias in Tripoli on 11 April. He was later released. Another colleague was also reported to have been taken away by an armed group. The CRA named the Bab Tajura brigade as their kidnappers. They accused them of haggling with him for a price in exchange for handing over access to the country's civil registry database.

column6: Rioters (Libya)
column17: An armed attack took place on the house of the governor of the Central Bank of Libya in Tripoli during protests against the devaluation of the Libyan currency.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: A 24 year-old Algerian nurse working in Misrata was kidnapped on 11 April. Her family fear that she has been abducted by Islamic State militants though no verification of this has been given.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Reports of renewed airstrikes targeting Misrata's ThirdForce/SDB in the area of Samnu.

column6: Misratah Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: Allegations that the Misratan Third Force killed four young Salafist supporters of the LNA at a checkpoint near the village of Samnu. Date unclear.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: In a reprisal attack for targeting the Tamanhint airbase, Misratan forces were reported to have attacked the LNA-controlled airbase in Brak Al-Shatti with Soviet-era aircraft, killing five.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)

Some locals have accused Haithem Tajouris Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade of setting alight the building which once housed Qaddafis General Peoples Congress. Others have accused the Mobile Forces which supports Khalifa Ghwell and is firmly opposed to Tajouri.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Airstrikes were reported on 13 April, three kilometres north of Sebha that reportedly targeted the premises of a Turkish company which the LNA apparently believed had been aiding the Misratan Third Force.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Protestors bricked up the Misrata municipality entrance in a move to try and demonstrate that Misrata's municipal council is no longer working. The opponents involved are reported to be allied to the rejectionist movement of would-be prime minister Khalifa Ghwell.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Libyan National Army Airforce airstrike this morning in Fattaih, south of Derna.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: The Libyan National Army (LNA) resumed airstrikes in the south attacking positions held by Misrata's Third Force near Sebha Airport, south-east of the town. There were no casualties.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Ten gunmen attacked a passport officer. The passport officer was severely beaten by members of a militia which is paid by the Government of National Accord (GNA) interior ministry to guard the airport. The militia was not named.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On April 15, LNA conducted two airstrikes targeting Shura Council of Darnah Mujahidin positions in Derna.

column6: Protesters (Libya)

column6: Al-Kanni Brigade
column17: Fighting in Tarhouna on 17 Apri left 15 people dead, almost all from the Basbusa family. Reports claim that those responsible were the local Kani brigade, a outwardly Islamist, family-controlled militia which now dominates the formerly pro-Qaddafi town. Members of the Basbusa family attacked the town's joint operations rooms after one of its members had been arrested. The brigade then allegedly attacked others of the Basbusa family.

The airbase was subjected to heavy artillery bombardment in the early hours of 18 April and the shelling destroyed the base's runway and caused damage to other buildings.

column6: Tabu Ethnic Militia (Libya)
column17: Fierce clashes reported on 24 April between rival Tebu and Awlad Sulaiman communities in central Sebha. These continued until 25 April. They followed a Tebu confiscation of a Awlad Sulaiman gas truck.

column6: Unidentified Military Forces
column17: An airstrike on a Tebu-run security headquarters and prison in Sebha on 24 April killed at least five and injured nine. Three prison inmates and two prison guards were killed. The attack was unclaimed. It destroyed large parts of the prison and vehicles outside. Tebu elders and political activists blamed forces linked to the 'interim government' (the Abdullah Thinn government in Beida). As many as 80 prisoners are said to have escaped from the prison as a result of the raid.

column6: Tabu Ethnic Militia (Libya)

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Benghazi's landmark Safina building was blown up by the Benghazi Revolutionaries Shoura Council (BRSC) militants in order to give them a clear line of fire from Suq Al-Hout which lies behind the now vanished edifice.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: Libya has seized two foreign-flagged oil tankers and detained their crews for allegedly smuggling fuel after an hours-long gunbattle off the west coast of Zuwarah. ""Boats with armed men were returned... and opened fire on the coastguards"" using Kalashnikovs and heavy machine guns. One of the vessels carried Ukrainian flag named Routa, with 14 crew members and 3,330 tons of diesel on board. The other one carried the flag Congo, named Stark, with nine crew members and 1,236 tons of diesel.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: One person was killed and two others wounded when a number of rocket-propelled grenades hit Benghazi's Leithi district on 1 May. A man is reported to have died when one of the grendes hit a lorry carrying bottles of cooking gas, causing it to explode.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: The Central Bank of Libya's operations manager was kidnapped. No further details were given.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Four mine clearance experts were killed in Sabri. The men from the Libyan National Army (LNA) engineers were trying to defuse an explosive device when it detonated killing all of them.

column6: Rioters (Libya)
column17: The Mayor of Misrata was forced to resign on 3 May by protestors who forced their way into a building where he was having a meeting. He subsequently announced that the resignation was not effective because he had been forced to act under duress and that he would continue in his role as per usual. Unconfirmed reports say gunshots were fired.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Three civilians were killed when a rocket hit a building in Shibna, part of Benghazi's Hay Dollar district. Accounts differ on the number of wounded but between seven and 14 people were take to Al-Jalaa hospital. It is reported that militants are claiming the rocket attack was in retaliation for air strikes on their positions in Sabri during which some of their number were killed.

column6: Awlad Suleiman Ethnic Militia (Libya)
column17: Gangland fighting erupted on 4 May in Sebha supposedly between members of the Awlad Sulaiman and Mahamid tribes, leaving a number of them dead. Estimates vary between six and 15 dead. The major said the clashes had nothing to do with the two tribes, that those involved were simply gangland criminals and most of them from other countries Libya. Only two of the dead were known to be Libyans, he claimed.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Staff at the Central Bank of Libya (CBL) in Tripoli demonstrated on 4 April in protest at the kidnapping of their director of banking operations, Fathi Al-Haji, by unidentified gunmen.

column6: Islamic State (Libya)
column17: Reports that two fighters from the Misratan Third Force were killed by suspected ISIS fighters near Wadi Allod, axis Abu Grein - Waddan.

column6: Military Forces of the United States (2017-)
column17: Reports citing 3rd Force field comm. says US aircraft conducted airstrike targeting an ISIS camp between Brak al-Shatti & Ashkda, near Sabha.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column17: A new video has emerged of a Libyan National Army (LNA) officer said to be a Saiqa Special Forces commander, executing a captured militant. It is claimed the video was taken in the last few days somewhere in Benghazi. The victim is reportedly an Algerian member of the so-called Islamic State who was said to have been caught trying to place a bomb under a vehicle.

column6: Fakhr Libya
column17: Explosions in Tripoli's Abu Sleem, Salahedeen and Airport Road districts late this evening have heightened fears of a major battle between hardline, mainly Misratan brigades and local brigades, notably those under Ghneiwa Al-Kikli, Haithem Al-Tajouri, Hashem Bishr and Abdul Raouf Kara. At the time of writing, there were no further details about the fighting, although there were reports that Ghneiwa's headquarters in Abu Sleem had been attacked. Explosions there are said to be the work of a group calling itself Fakhr Libya ('Pride of Libya' - ___ _____).

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Tripoli University announced that classes in all faculties are stopped until further notice.The students' union and staff are said to have jointly agreed today's decision. Both are reported to be extremely angry and events, blaming the authorities and military forces for the situation. Two staff members have been abducted in the past three weeks.

column17: There have been fierce clashes in Benghazi's Suq Al-Hout district today as the Libyan National Army (LNA) continued to assault militant positions. The LNA has given no details of the fighting nor of casualties on either side.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: A commander of Benghazi's police emergency response unit, the najdah, was killed in the early hours of the morning when gunmen attacked his vehicle near the unit's headquarters in the city's Birkah district. Allegations that elements from Saiqa special forces were to blame have been denied by the brigade. In a statement, it says that the killing appears to have been related to a private feud. An investigation has been launched into what happened, it adds. It also warns social media activists against using the story to attack the brigade and trying to cause dissension among those fighting against terrorism.

column17: An attack on an airbase in south Libya has killed 141 people, mostly soldiers loyal to military strongman Khalifa Haftar, a spokesman for his forces said on Friday.Members of the Third Force militia loyal to the UN-backed Government of National Accord in Tripoli on Thursday attacked the base used by Haftar's self-proclaimed Libyan National Army (LNA), military sources said earlier.LNA spokesman Ahmad al-Mesmari late Friday said the victims included civilians who worked at the Brak al-Shati airbase or were in the nearby area, also reporting that summary executions took place.

column17: Benghazi member of the House of Representatives, Badr Musa Al-Nahib Alaguri, was shot at today as he was leaving Friday prayers at a mosque in the Masakin area of the city's Buatni district. He suffered minor injuries.The shooting is thought to be linked to the assassination of Breik Ellawati, one of the leaders of the Awagir tribe. Apart from both being members of the same tribe, the two attacks happened at the same time.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: The head of eastern Libya's largest tribe was killed on Friday when a car bomb exploded outside a mosque on the outskirts of Benghazi. ""Sheikh Abrik al-Luwati, the head of the Al-Awaqir tribe, was killed by a car bomb after leaving the Bilal bin Rabah Mosque in Benghazi's Sallouq district,"" an official said.""The bombing also killed al-Luwati's son and another man."" No group has yet claimed responsibility for the deadly attack.

No casualty figures have been announced, but LNA spokesman Colonel Ahmed Mismari has said that three enemy fighters were captured and the militia's leader wounded.

column17: The crew of a Libyan speedboat with the label of Libyan Coastguard fired shots at migrant boats during a rescue operation, said an NGO working in migrant rescue operations in the central Mediterranean on Wednesday.

column6: Tuareg Ethnic Militia (Libya)
column17: Misratan militias quitted the Sharara oil field, which was handed over week to a Tuareg militia led by Ali Kana. Locals report that the transfer was peaceful.

column17: The Libyan National Army (LNA) has retaken Tamenhint airbase from mainly Misratan fighters. The Misratan 13th Brigade, formerly the Third Force, withdrew from Tamenhint and headed north to Jufra.

column17: At least 28 people were killed and nearly 130 wounded in fierce clashes on Friday between forces loyal to the UN-backed unity government and rival militiamen led by pro-GNC factions led by Fakhr Libya, the health ministry said.

column17: At least 28 people were killed and nearly 130 wounded in fierce clashes on Friday between forces loyal to the UN-backed unity government and rival militiamen led by pro-GNC factions led by Fakhr Libya, the health ministry said.

column6: Islamic State (Libya)
column17: Reports from Benghazi indicate that IS had established a base near Abu Grain, halfway between Misrata and Sirte, and which Misratan forces recaptured from IS a year ago. According to sources, IS fighters and black flags were to be seen in the area. One Abu Grain resident now in Benghazi, says that the militants are not based in any one place for any length of time, however. Comparing them to locusts, he said that they had raided a number of villages in search of food and booty, but then left.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On May 26, LNA conducted four airstrikes targeting Shura Council of Darnah Mujahidin positions in Derna.

column6: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade
column7: Government of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: Militia commander Haitham Tajouri and his Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade (TRB) seized Hadba prison late last night. They also demolished the house of its controller, Khaled Al-Sharif. All prisoners had been transferred, including Saadi Qaddafi and former intelligence chief Abdullah Senussi. The death of three military leaders was reported during this operation. The health ministry said the total number of fatalities from the clash was 47.

column6: Military Forces of Egypt (2014-)
column7: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Egypt launched six air strikes on militant camps in Libya Friday after masked gunmen attacked a bus of Coptic Christians south of the Egyptian capital, killing at least 28 people. A spokesman for the Majlis Mujahedeen Derna, which controls the city, said the Egyptian air force carried out eight raids on the city without causing casualties.

column9: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: Jufra airbase came under attack twice today by planes believed to belong to the Egyptian airforce. As well as the base itself, held by Misratan forces plus members of the Benghazi Defence Brigades (BDB), a nearby headquarters of a separate Misratan unit is also said to have been hit. At one point the explosions were reported being very loud, suggesting that an ammunitions depot had been hit.

At least three militiamen are reported to have killed, one of who has been named as Suhail Ben Kora.

column6: Brigades for the Defence of Benghazi
column17: The Benghazi Defence Brigades (BDB) have retreated to Sabratha according to Libya's former UN ambassador Ibrahim al-Dabbashi. Writing on his Facebook page yesterday, he said that the BDB, which he called 'a terrorist organisation', was trying to occupy the town in alliance with Al-Qaeda elements in the town. Dabbashi, whose family is from Sabratha, warned the town not to 'repeat the fatal mistake' of allowing the BDB to remain. Its presence would create divisions with the town and be an excuse for others to attack. In the end, it would have to be fought.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Libya-focused Afrigate News website reported that hundreds of people took to the streets of smaller Libyan towns to celebrate Saif Gaddafi's release. Among the towns in which celebrations were reported to have taken place were those that are still viewed as bastions of support for the Gaddafi era, such as Bani Walid and Sabha.

column17: The Libyan National Army (LNA) has today breached rubble barricades and captured a key building in Benghazi's Suq Al-Hout district forcing the militants to withdraw further into the old city. One solider died and four were injured in the operation to take over the former Internal Security building. The adverse BRSC is still present in Suq al Hout and as-Sabry.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: The Benghazi's iconic Tahrir Square and the courthouse that faces it was today taken from militants by the Libyan National Army (LNA). Troops are moving further into Suq Al Hout, the penultimate enclave held by Islamist fighters. Air strikes have continued throughout the day. It is reported that Al-Zawia Al-Rifaiya had been taken and there have been intermittent clashes in the Municipal Square.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: LNA air strikes on Souq al-Hout in Benghazi have continued throughout the day. Today a soldier was killed and two companions injured when a device, thought to be a land mine, exploded as they searched the former internal security headquarters which the LNA overran yesterday. Troops have been ordered out of the building until it has been cleared by engineering units. A shell apparently fired from Sabri, landed close to the Jalaa hospital but failed to explode. The hospital is the main reception centre for LNA wounded.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On June 14, LNA conducted one airstrike targeting an unidentified armed group in Sebha.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries

While there are no reports of LNA casualties today, the bodies of at least two militants were discovered. Bombardment continued overnight.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)

column17: Two men were injured, one seriously, when a bomb placed under a vehicle blew up in a car in Ajdabiya last night. The incident occurred near the Aisha girls' school in the town's Fallujah district. One of the injured is reported to be Makki Absit Al-Zwai, the brother of Mohamed Absit Al-Zwai, commander of the Libyan National Army's 21st border guard brigade. His companion, named as Abdul Salam Al-Harak, is said to have been seriously wounded. Absit, a member of the brigade, sustained leg injuries.

Simultaneously, the Libyan Air Force carried air raids over the Benghazi,"" the report said.

The demonstrators claimed that fuel deliveries heading to the town were being diverted by smugglers. They also accused elements in the fuel distribution industry of being corrupt and bribed.

The LNA has given no figures for its losses over the past two days and since last week has not reported the death or capture of any militants. However medical sources indicate at least 44 LNA soldiers died during June (12 fatalities added to meet total).

As he left it, he detonated his suicide vest, killing himself but only lightly injuring a member of the security forces.

It has not been named, although according to one report, the problem was the result of in-fighting between two groups at the airport involved in smuggling in Bangladeshi workers into the country.

column6: Islamic State (Libya)
column17: Looting: IS seized two fuel trucks south of Sirte as the vehicles made their way from Zawia to the south. The Fuel and Gas Crisis Committee (FAGCC) has decided that fuel movements cannot continue until the Presidency Council (PC) and the local authorities in the area secure the route to the south.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: A militiaman with the Rahbat Al-Droua brigade which is based in the east Tripoli district of Tajoura was shot dead early yesterday morning in the capital's downtown area of Zawiat Al-Dahmani. At present, the reason for his killing is unknown. Even the circumstances remain unclear. Some reports say that he was killed following an argument with two other men. However, on its Facebook page, the brigade says that he was in his car when unknown gunmen shot at him. They then fled.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Two soldiers of the Libyan National Army (LNA) were killed and four wounded in a landmine explosion in the eastern city of Benghazi's Souq al-Hout neighbourhood, a Libyan news website reported on 22 June. The landmine explosion also destroyed two vehicles, the report said.

column6: Misratah Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: A group of activists and their families who tried to return to their homes in Tawergha today were forced back just a dozen kilometres from the town by Misratan militiamen who allegedly fired at them.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: The Libyan National Army (LNA) says it has finally taken full control of Benghazi's central Suq Al-Hout area. LNA spokesman Colonel Ahmed Mismari told the Libya Herald that the whole area had now been liberated, although it had lost six men in the fighting today, one of them a commander. Later reports put the total number of fatalities in the latest offensive on 23 and 24 June to 13.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries

column17: Three LNA soldiers from the elite Saiq unit were killed today in a mine explosion in Lathama district which is near Sabri. Later reports put the total number of fatalities in the latest offensive on 23 and 24 June to 13.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Yesterday evening an army colonel from the Shatti area but who lived in semi-retirement in Tripoli, was killed along with his 20-year-old daughter as they drove off from their home in the capital's Ain Zara district, not far from Salahadeen. The occupant of a car blocking the end of the road got out and shot at them with a Kalashnikov. According to the member of Hasnawi's family, the colonel was targeted because the killer had a grudge against the Hasawna tribe whom he blamed for his brother's death at the time of the breakout from Wadi Al-Shatti's Gurda prison in February.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Offensives in Benghazi over 23-24 June left 13 killed.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Sabri was subjected to a series of airstrikes. LNA commanders have used fixed camera and regular drone flights to monitor militant activity and pinpoint likely strongpoints. Offensives in Benghazi over 23-24 June left 13 killed.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Two soldiers have died in fighting in Benghazi's Sabri district as the Libyan National Army (LNA) moves its forces forward from Suq Al-Hout finally taken from militants on Friday.

column6: Islamic State (Libya)
column17: A member of Muammar Qaddafi's Qaddadfa tribe is thought to have been kidnapped by militants of the so-called Islamic State (IS). Tribal elders said that Mohammed Abubakr Abusadra Qaddafi, who they described as a former soldier, had disappeared near Qasr Abu Hadi, some 70 kilometres south of Sirte, near Gardabaya airport.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On June 26, LNA conducted three airstrikes targeting BRSC or Islamic State militant positions in Benghazi.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: A Libyan young man on Tuesday burned himself in the Martyrs' Square in central Tripoli. Social media said the young man burnt himself in protest against his poor living conditions.

column6: Military Forces of Egypt (2014-)
column17: On June 27, Egyptian warplanes struck a convoy of 12 vehicles about to be driven across the border from Libyan-Egyptian border (coded as Jaghbub at geoprecision 2) carrying weapons and ammunition, the military said on Tuesday. The military said in a statement that it had acted on ""intelligence indicating a number of criminal elements had gathered to cross the border into Egypt using a number of four-wheel-drive vehicles"". An official in the armed forces told AFP the vehicles had been on the move from Libya.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: In Benghazi's Sabri district today, there has been more heavy fighting in which at least three fighters have died and a significant number have been injured. The LNA has not issued official casualty figures but there has been a steady flow of ambulances taking the wounded away from the frontline. The LNA spokesman later addead a post on facebook, to note a number of streets and a school in Sabri that had so far been recaptured in the latest operation.

column6: Unidentified Military Forces
column17: On June 28, an unknown aircraft conducted two airstrikes targeting presumed BRSC or Islamic State militant positions in Benghazi.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: A single shell fired from militants inside Sabri landed in the Salmani district on the Shamal football ground, damaging shops but causing no casualties.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column9: UNSMIL: United Nations Support Mission in Libya (2011-)
column17: Gunmen attacked a UN convoy near Libya's capital and abducted seven staff members on Wednesday before releasing them unharmed, a top security official in the conflict-wracked country said. General Najmi al-Nakoua of the presidential guard service said the attack on the convoy took place near Zawiyah, about 50 kilometres (30 miles) west of the capital Tripoli.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction

column8: Government of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: Elders from Libya's Tebu and Awlad Suleiman tribes have handed over control of the southern Libyan international airport of Sabha to the local security directorate there, several media outlets reported on 2 July. It cited GNA Minister for Local Administration Bidad Qansoua as telling the channel that the airport's handover was a result of direct negotiation between the clashing sides and that the facility was fully functional and ready for use.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column9: Government of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: The education minister in Presidency Council's government of national accord came under fire this morning when his convoy was shot at by an unidentified group as it passed by a checkpoint south of Sebha its way to Murzuk. The minister was whisked away by some of his security team from Checkpoint 17 but the unknown militia briefly detained other members. They were later released following the intervention of local elders. One person is believed to have been slightly injured but no other casualties have been reported. In a subsequent statement on the social media platform, a ministry spokesman said that the incident was ""criminal and was not politically motivated"".

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: The Libyan National Army (LNA) says it made major advances in Benghazi's Sabri district Monday forcing the militants to retreat to the Gomhuriya Hospital. A medical source talking to reuters said on Tuesday that since Monday, at least 16 troops have died and 36 been injured in the two days of clashes in Benghazi. The LNA furthermore says that 19 militants have been killed.

column6: Al-Buni Brigade
column17: Stray fire from fighting between factions of the Al-Buni Brigade that control Libya's Mitiga airport killed five people at a nearby beach and forced the suspension of flights on Wednesday, authorities said. A rocket from the clashes hit a beach across from the airport, killing a child and wounding 25 other people, the health ministry said late Tuesday, before raising the death toll to five.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Looting: An armed group has stormed and ransacked the offices of the Zawia traffic police. The unidentified militia burst through the front entrance and threatened the director and others in the building with their guns. They stole air conditioning units, computers and several files. They then went to the traffic divisions car park though it is unclear if they seized any vehicles.

column6: Rioters (Libya)
column17: Flights to and from Tobruk have been disrupted as young demonstrators blockaded Tobruk airport's only fuel depot demanding jobs. Tobruk Airport boss Hasan Halil said today that he had no control over who Brega Oil hired. But because under Civil Aviation Authority rules aircraft had to be able to refuel at Tobruk, he said that he had no alternative than to once again close the airport.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column7: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: The Libyan National Army (LNA) has today taken further ground in Sabri. Today's thrust involved the Saiqa Special Forces and their commander Wanis Bukhamada was pictured near the front line. A medical source talking to reuters said on Tuesday that since Monday, at least 16 troops have died and 36 been injured in the two days of clashes in Benghazi. The LNA furthermore says that 19 militants have been killed.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: LNA forces coming from Harawa launched attack on Bunyan al Marsous (Misrata militia) positions with clashes at gate 17 east of Sirte which was repelled by the militia.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column7: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: In a rapid advance today Libyan National Army (LNA) forces overran militant positions in Benghazi's Sabri district, taking Gumhoriya Hospital and the unfinished Hyatt Regency hotel. This evening as most soldiers celebrated victory, some troops were surrounding buildings in the Sidi Akribesh area where the last gunmen were holding out. The final battle has seen five more LNA deaths, including Colonel Saleh Al-Rishi. Four militants, one of them wounded, were captured.

column6: Al-Buni Brigade
column17: Mitiga airport has been shut today as fighting rages between rival members of the same militia. The health ministry said this morning that 32 people had so far been injured. The fighting is between rival members of the Buni Brigade which controls the airport terminal building. It is understood that there had been a falling out over the distribution of the income the militia earns from goods and passengers passing through the terminal. The original dispute started when one Buni Brigade member was killed by another, at which point the two different factions set on each other.

column6: Misratah Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: According to Bunyan Marsous Forces (Misrata) in Sirte, an attack by the Islamic State was fended off.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On July 6, LNA conducted fourteen airstrikes against BRSC or Islamic State militant positions in Benghazi.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Libyans have celebrated the declaration that Libyan National Army (LNA) has ""fully liberated"" the city of Benghazi after three years of fighting against Islamist militias. Celebratory gunshots were fired into the sky and rallies held at night in Benghazi and other cities, such as Alrujban.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Libyans have celebrated the declaration that Libyan National Army (LNA) has ""fully liberated"" the city of Benghazi after three years of fighting against Islamist militias. column17: Three soldiers attached to Libyan National Army (LNA) and two of their friends were found shot dead today in Wadi Rabie, near Tripoli International Airport.The three were members of Brigade 103, which belongs to the LNA's western command. The men were shot while off-duty and visiting friends and family in the capital for the first time in a long time. They had then gone missing, only to be found dead at dawn this morning.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Four LNA soldiers, including an unnamed field commander, died today as troops tried to seize the very last militant positions in a few buildings in Benghazi's Sidi Akribesh. The deaths come 48 hours after armed forces commander-in-chief Khalifa Hafter announced the liberation of the city.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction

column17: At least 18 Libyan National Army (LNA) soldiers were killed today as the fight to conclude the Battle of Benghazi went into its third day. It was the heaviest confirmed LNA death toll within a twenty-four hour period for some weeks.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: The head of the national security directorate in Gharyan, 80 kilometres south of Tripoli, was murdered last night by unknown gunmen in front of his house.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction

There are unconfirmed reports that two more soldiers were killed in the last hours of the battle.

column6: Misratah Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: A number of local residents are reported to have been killed and injured as a result of indiscriminate rocket fire during fighting today in Garabulli, east of Tripoli, between mainly Misratan forces supporting Khalifa Ghwell's 'national salvation government' (NSG) and Tripoli forces backing the Presidency Council.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Three LNA soldiers were killed Sunday in mine blasts as they carried out search operations in Al-Sabri and Soug al-Hout, according to the LNA spokesperson.

column17: Three LNA soldiers were killed Sunday in mine blasts as they carried out search operations in Al-Sabri and Soug al-Hout, according to the LNA spokesperson.

column17: Fighting between Misratan forces and forces from Tripoli continued. On tripoli said, different militias moved back to the capital, leaving only the Tripoli Revoluionaries brigade in the battlefield. According to reports 2 civilians died while the number of dead fighters in unknown.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Three Libyan National Army (LNA) soldiers died in mine and boobytrap explosions today. It is being reported that one of the deaths came when a soldier was helping a family return to their Sabri home.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Three soldiers were injured in Benghazi this morning when a militant, who had apparently escaped from Sid Akribesh, blew himself up when he was cornered. The militant, who said said to be a Tunisian, was found in a school opposite the Al-Najma football club in the Salmani district. When troops advanced to detain him he detonated a suicide vest or a grenade. Another man with him was however captured.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Three Libyan National Army (LNA) soldiers died in mine and boobytrap explosions today. It is being reported that one of the deaths came when a soldier was helping a family return to their Sabri home.

column17: On July 10, an unknown aircraft struck an unidentified target in Benghazi.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On July 10, LNA aircrafts conducted two airstrikes against Shura Council of Darnah Mujahidin positions in Derna, one of which killed three individuals.

column6: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade
column17: Fighting which has raged since Sunday in and around Garabulli, to the east of Tripoli, has died down today. The violent artillery and gunfire exchanges have reportedly seen some 85 percent of the townspeople flee. But the battle may be moving elsewhere.The Tripoli Revolutionaries' Brigade (TRB) claimed today to be in complete control of the town. It had advanced to Garabulli to block a push on the capital from Misrata by forces backing former premier Khalifa Ghwell. Misratan forces are now to be said to try to invade Tripoli from the south. Later reports say that as a result of the clashes 4 people died over the days.

column6: Unidentified Clan Militia (Libya)
column9: Government of Libya (2014-) House of Representatives
column17: An official working for the government has been murdered as part of an 'ongoing vendetta' between families.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: In the last ten days 20 civilians have been killed or injured in explosions in Suq Al-Hout and Sabri, the last two areas of Benghazi in which the militants held out until finally defeated last week.

column17: In the last ten days 20 civilians have been killed or injured in explosions in Suq Al-Hout and Sabri, the last two areas of Benghazi in which the militants held out until finally defeated last week.

The militia had occupied the cement works since 2015 and had used it a lucrative source of funding. The Kani brigade return with tanks and weapons and battle the locals to regain control of the cement works. Four locals die during the two day battle.

column6: Islamic State (Libya)

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Angry protesters on Sunday shut down the only landfill in Tobruk after the deadline given by citizens to the municipal council expired. Protester demand the municipal council to find another alternative to this landfill because of its proximity to residential neighborhoods.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On Sunday afternoon, an attempt by fighters from the Derna Mujahedeen Shoura Council (DMSC) to break through the Libyan National Army (LNA)'s blockade of the town ended in failure this morning and appears to have given the LNA the chance to take the Kasarat area in the eastern part. The move came as the head of the LNA's Omar Mukhtar Operations Room tasked with taking Derna declared that there would now be a total blockade.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: In Sabratha, some 500 LNA-linked forces from the Watiya airbase and nearby towns clashed with the militia led by Ahmed Dabbashi, a member of a prominent local family with a record of Islamist support. No casualty figures have emerged but the engagement ended with the militiamen pulling out of the town. Tonight they are reported to be 20 kilometres away. Other local pro-Islamist militias are also understood to have quit the town. It seems unlikely the LNA-linked force has occupied much of Sabratha, though a post with a photograph of a vehicle sporting a decal reading 'Special Task Forces' suggested this possibility.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: A number of activists in the city of Sabha on Monday organized a solidarity protest with the constituent body to draft the draft constitution. The solidarity activists demanded the Libyan people unite to stand against those who want to divide Libya. They also stressed that the unity of Libyan soil is the basis of the unity of the Libyans.

column6: Police Forces of Libya (2016-)
column17: The LNA arrived east of Sirte and set up a checkpoint 50km east of the city. There is a state of alert in the city. Bullets were heard from time to time, and checkpoints were set up at the entrances and exits of the city, a checkpoint at the administrative complex in the center of the city and another point at the entrance to the popular neighborhood. Sources confirmed that the city's protection force shot and wounded two people who refused to stand at a checkpoint.

column6: Protesters (Libya)

The protest was launched in partnership with civil society organizations in the city and the municipal council.

A pipeline supplying jet fuel and gasoline from Zawiya to Tripoli that the men had also closed has reopened, the NOC added.

column17: On August 16, LNA conducted two airstrikes targeting Shura Council of Darnah Mujahidin positions in Derna.

column17: Heavy clashes have continued for the third day between rival armed groups in Libya'swestern town of Ujailat, forcing local residents to flee the centre of the city. Continuous fighting between militiamen from the Sheikh Abu Bakr Abu Snina Brigade and rival fighters from a local family led to one fatality and an an unknown number of casualties. The clashes between two local militias flared up after they enlisted support of armed groups from the cities of Sabratha and Zawiya.

column6: Ajilat Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: After four days of heavy fighting in Ajilat, some 80 kilometres west of Tripoli, a ceasefire has been mediated by members of the local council together with elders from the Wershifana, Zintan and other nearby towns.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On August 17, LNA conducted two airstrikes targeting Shura Council of Darnah Mujahidin positions in Derna.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: 4 female students were abducted at Tripoli university on Thursday. Among them there is one professor.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction - Saiqa Forces
column17: Arrests: The Libyan National Army said that Saiqa-commander Mahmoud al-Werfalli was arrested in the context of a arrest warrant by the International Criminal Court, accusing him of war crimes. It is not clear if the LNA is ready to hand over Werfalli to the ICC.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: A unit from the Libyan National Army's 12th Battalion was attacked at dawn this morning near Brak Al-Shatti by an armed group. Three soldiers were wounded in the assault which took place at the Dabwat agricultural project south of Brak airbase. They were taken to the 2nd March Hospital in Sebha but one of them died from his injuries some hours later.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Members of the Warfalla tribe protested in Bani Walid to denounce the arrest warrant by the International Criminal Court against al-Werfall who is being accused of warcrimes.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: A 25-year-old man named as Isra Ghaith Al-Warfali was seized by a four-man gang near the Tajoura heart hospital.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Members of the Warfalla tribe protested in Sebha to denounce the arrest warrant by the International Criminal Court against al-Werfall who is being accused of war crimes.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: A child in Benghazi's as-Sabri district died due to stepping on a landmine. Landmines were placed by the Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries before they have been defeated.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Unknown gunmen fired shots on the car of a bureaucrat supervising the education system in Gharyan. No one was injured.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: One of the deans of Senussi university in al-Bayda disappared. It is assumed that he was kidnapped.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On August 21, LNA conducted two airstrikes targeting Shura Council of Darnah Mujahidin positions in Derna.

column6: Military Forces of Egypt (2014-)
column17: On August 21, Egypt conducted three airstrikes targeting vehicles of an unidentified armed group on the Libyan-Egyptian border (coded as Jaghbub at geoprecision 2).

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Workers at an agricultural project entered a sit-in for more than 21 days to demand that the LNA properly manages its project, accusing the army of tampering with the public interest.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: The home of a leading member of the Misrata Youth Movement (MYM) was shot by gunmen who then fled. The MYM has been outspoken in its support for national reconciliation and its criticism of those in the city who it sees as obstructing this.

column6: Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade
column7: Government of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
column17: Agreement: Ali Zeidan, former Prime Minister who was kidnapped one week ago, was released. It was reported that the Tripoli Revolutionaries Brigade, allied to the Government of National Accord, was responsible for the kidnapping.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Two people were injured as they were stepping on landmines while inspecting their homes. Landmines were placed by the Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries before they have been defeated.

column6: Islamic State (Libya)
column8: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: 9 soldiers from the Libyan National Army were beheaded 23 August in an attack claimed by the Islamic State group on Fuqaha checkpoint.

column6: Islamic State (Libya)
column17: 2 civilians were beheaded 23 August in an attack claimed by the Islamic State jihadist group on Fuqaha checkpoint, manned by forces of the Libyan National Army.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Fighting between two groups outside a bank in Khoms this morning is said to have left several people injured. The trouble apparently started after the delivery of LD 5 million to the town's Sahara Bank.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: Supporters of controversial Libya National Army (LNA) officer Mahmoud Al-Warfali took to the streets of Benghazi yesterday to protest the ICC's arrest warrant for him.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On August 25, LNA conducted two airstrikes targeting Shura Council of Darnah Mujahidin positions in Derna.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: The brother of Muhammad Issa al-Falah, Salim al-Falah, was kidnapped by unknown men.

column6: Zawiya Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: Agreement: Tebu and Zawiya tribe agreed to exchange 11 abductees of each other's tribes.

column6: Al-Kanni Brigade
column17: Militiamen from Tarhouna raided the family home of Major al-Suwai, a former officer under Gaddafi, and killed him. In reprisal, members of the family reportedly attacked members of the brigade from Tarhouna and killed three of them.

column6: Subol Al-Salam Brigade
column7: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: Fighting took place near the Libyan-Chadian-border between a group of Chadian opposition fighters and the Sabl al-Salam battalion, which belongs to the Libyan National army. The bataillon consists mainly of members of the Zwai tribe. Seven Chadian fighters and two members of battalion were killed in the fighting.

column6: Rioters (Libya)
column17: A brigade tasked with oil facilities protection has blocked production at the Al-Fil (Elephant)-field, located in Western Libya to protest against the marginalisation of the region.

column6: Ajilat Communal Militia (Libya)
column17: Clashes between rival armed groups in Ajaylat.

column6: Al-Kanni Brigade
column17: Militiamen from Tarhouna raided the family home of Major al-Suwai, a former officer under Gaddafi, and killed him. In reprisal, members of the family reportedly attacked members of the brigade from Tarhouna and killed three of them.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On 27 August 2017: Libyan National Army established a new military base in Brak al-Shati, 120 km north of sabha.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Al-Sarhani, a civil society activist, was kidnapped on August 27. His family believes the reason for kidnapping to be his belonging to Sufism. More than 1 month later he was still not released.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Non-violent activity: A brigade tasked with oil facilities protection has closed a pipeline leading to the Hamada field.

column6: Rioters (Libya)
column17: A local Libyan brigade closed down two valves on a pipeline to Sharara oilfield, the country's largest, to make demands for more fuel supplies and better economic conditions for the Zintan region.

column6: Protesters (Libya)
column17: On Sunday, a protest rally was held in front of the headquarters of the Municipal Council in the city of Sabha to demand the dismissal of the director of the Sabha oil depot, the tightening of control over gas and gas distribution stations.

column6: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: Three people were injured as they were stepping on landmines. Landmines were placed by the Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries before they have been defeated.

column6: Al-Kanni Brigade
column7: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column17: The Kani brigade killed 10 members of the Suwai family in revenge killings in Rgaiat and nearby Suq Al-Khamis Emsihel on 27 August. Clashes reportedly involved young armed residents and the militia.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Libya)
column17: Sufi activist Abd Elmatlob Serhani who left his home on 27 August has not been seen since. It is thought that his disappearance may be connected to criticism from him against the growth of Salafism within the military.

column6: Al-Kanni Brigade
column7: BRSC: Shura Council of Benghazi Revolutionaries
column9: Military Forces of Libya (2016-) Government of National Accord
